books.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:1
verses.text: Dogmatical and Historical: Treatise on Christ and Antichrist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:2
verses.text: As it was your desire, my beloved brother Theophilus, to be thoroughly informed on those topics which I put summarily before you, I have thought it right to set these matters of inquiry clearly forth to your view, drawing largely from the Holy Scriptures themselves as from a holy fountain, in order that you may not only have the pleasure of hearing them on the testimony of men, but may also be able, by surveying them in the light of (divine) authority, to glorify God in all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:3
verses.text: For this will be as a sure supply furnished you by us for your journey in this present life, so that by ready argument applying things ill understood and apprehended by most, you may sow them in the ground of your heart, as in a rich and clean soil.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:4
verses.text: By these, too, you will be able to silence those who oppose and gainsay the word of salvation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:5
verses.text: Only see that you do not give these things over to unbelieving and blasphemous tongues, for that is no common danger.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:6
verses.text: But impart them to pious and faithful men, who desire to live holily and righteously with fear.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:7
verses.text: For it is not to no purpose that the blessed apostle exhorts Timothy, and says, "O Timothy, keep that which is committed to thy trust, avoiding profane and vain babblings, and oppositions of science falsely so called; which some professing have erred concerning the faith".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:8
verses.text: And again, "Thou therefore, my son, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:9
verses.text: And the things that thou hast heard of me in many exhortations, the same commit thou to faithful men, who shall be able to teach others also".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:10
verses.text: If, then, the blessed (apostle) delivered these things with a pious caution, which could be easily known by all, as he perceived in the spirit that "all men have not faith," how much greater will be our danger, if, rashly and without thought, we commit the revelations of God to profane and unworthy men?.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:11
verses.text: For as the blessed prophets were made, so to speak, eyes for us, they foresaw through faith the mysteries of the word, and became ministers of these things also to succeeding generations, not only reporting the past, but also announcing the present and the future, so that the prophet might not appear to be one only for the time being, but might also predict the future for all generations, and so be reckoned a (true) prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:12
verses.text: For these fathers were furnished with the Spirit, and largely honoured by the Word Himself; and just as it is with instruments of music, so had they the Word always, like the plectrum, in union with them, and when moved by Him the prophets announced what God willed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:13
verses.text: For they spake not of their own power (let there be no mistake as to that), neither did they declare what pleased themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:14
verses.text: But first of all they were endowed with wisdom by the Word, and then again were rightly instructed in the future by means of visions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:15
verses.text: And then, when thus themselves fully convinced, they spake those things which were revealed by God to them alone, and concealed from all others.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:16
verses.text: For with what reason should the prophet be called a prophet, unless he in spirit foresaw the future? For if the prophet spake of any chance event, he would not be a prophet then in speaking of things which were under the eye of all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:17
verses.text: But one who sets forth in detail things yet to be, was rightly judged a prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:18
verses.text: Wherefore prophets were with good reason called from the very first "seers".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:19
verses.text: And hence we, too, who are rightly instructed in what was declared aforetime by them, speak not of our own capacity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:20
verses.text: For we do not attempt to make any change one way or another among ourselves in the words that were spoken of old by them, but we make the Scriptures in which these are written public, and read them to those who can believe rightly; for that is a common benefit for both parties: for him who speaks, in holding in memory and setting forth correctly things uttered of old; and for him who hears, in giving attention to the things spoken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:21
verses.text: Since, then, in this there is a work assigned to both parties together, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:22
verses.text: , to him who speaks, that he speak forth faithfully without regard to risk, and to him who hears, that he hear and receive in faith that which is spoken, I beseech you to strive together with me in prayer to God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:23
verses.text: Do you wish then to know in what manner the Word of God, who was again the Son of God, as He was of old the Word, communicated His revelations to the blessed prophets in former times? Well, as the Word shows His compassion and His denial of all respect of persons by all the saints, He enlightens them and adapts them to that which is advantageous for us, like a skilful physician, understanding the weakness of men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:24
verses.text: And the ignorant He loves to teach, and the erring He turns again to His own true way.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:25
verses.text: And by those who live by faith He is easily found; and to those of pure eye and holy heart, who desire to knock at the door, He opens immediately.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:26
verses.text: For He casts away none of His servants as unworthy of the divine mysteries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:27
verses.text: He does not esteem the rich man more highly than the poor, nor does He despise the poor man for his poverty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:28
verses.text: He does not disdain the barbarian, nor does He set the eunuch aside as no man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:29
verses.text: He does not hate the female on account of the woman's act of disobedience in the beginning, nor does He reject the male on account of the man's transgression.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:30
verses.text: But He seeks all, and desires to save all, wishing to make all the children of God, and calling all the saints unto one perfect man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:31
verses.text: For there is also one Son (or Servant) of God, by whom we too, receiving the regeneration through the Holy Spirit, desire to come all unto one perfect and heavenly man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:32
verses.text: For whereas the Word of God was without flesh, He took upon Himself the holy flesh by the holy Virgin, and prepared a robe which He wove for Himself, like a bridegroom, in the sufferings of the cross, in order that by uniting His own power with our mortal body, and by mixing the incorruptible with the corruptible, and the strong with the weak, He might save perishing man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:33
verses.text: The web-beam, therefore, is the passion of the Lord upon the cross, and the warp on it is the power of the Holy Spirit, and the woof is the holy flesh wrought (woven) by the Spirit, and the thread is the grace which by the love of Christ binds and unites the two in one, and the combs or (rods) are the Word; and the workers are the patriarchs and prophets who weave the fair, long, perfect tunic for Christ; and the Word passing through these, like the combs or (rods), completes through them that which His Father willeth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:34
verses.text: But as time now presses for the consideration of the question immediately in hand, and as what has been already said in the introduction with regard to the glory of God, may suffice, it is proper that we take the Holy Scriptures themselves in hand, and find out from them what, and of what manner, the coming of Antichrist is; on what occasion and at what time that impious one shall be revealed; and whence and from what tribe (he shall come); and what his name is, which is indicated by the number in the Scripture; and how he shall work error among the people, gathering them from the ends of the earth; and (how) he shall stir up tribulation and persecution against the saints; and how he shall glorify himself as God; and what his end shall be; and how the sudden appearing of the Lord shall be revealed from heaven; and what the conflagration of the whole world shall be; and what the glorious and heavenly kingdom of the saints is to be, when they reign together with Christ; and what the punishment of the wicked by fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:35
verses.text: Now, as our Lord Jesus Christ, who is also God, was prophesied of under the figure of a lion, on account of His royalty and glory, in the same way have the Scriptures also aforetime spoken of Antichrist as a lion, on account of his tyranny and violence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:36
verses.text: For the deceiver seeks to liken himself in all things to the Son of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:37
verses.text: Christ is a lion, so Antichrist is also a lion; Christ is a king, so Antichrist is also a king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:38
verses.text: The Saviour was manifested as a lamb; so he too, in like manner, will appear as a lamb, though within he is a wolf.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:39
verses.text: The Saviour came into the world in the circumcision, and he will come in the same manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:40
verses.text: The Lord sent apostles among all the nations, and he in like manner will send false apostles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:41
verses.text: The Saviour gathered together the sheep that were scattered abroad, and he in like manner will bring together a people that is scattered abroad.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:42
verses.text: The Lord gave a seal to those who believed on Him, and he will give one in like manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:43
verses.text: The Saviour appeared in the form of man, and he too will come in the form of a man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:44
verses.text: The Saviour raised up and showed His holy flesh like a temple, and he will raise a temple of stone in Jerusalem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:45
verses.text: And his seductive arts we shall exhibit in what follows.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:46
verses.text: But for the present let us turn to the question in hand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:47
verses.text: Now the blessed Jacob speaks to the following effect in his benedictions, testifying prophetically of our Lord and Saviour: "Judah, let thy brethren praise thee: thy hand shall be on the neck of thine enemies; thy father's children shall bow down before thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:48
verses.text: Judah is a lion's whelp: from the shoot, my son, thou art gone up: he stooped down, he couched as a lion, and as a lion's whelp; who shall rouse him up? A ruler shall not depart from Judah, nor a leader from his thighs, until he come for whom it is reserved; and he shall be the expectation of the nations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:49
verses.text: Binding his ass to a vine, and his ass's colt to the vine tendril; he shall wash his garment in wine, and his clothes in the blood of the grapes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:50
verses.text: His eyes shall be gladsome as with wine, and his teeth shall be whiter than milk".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:51
verses.text: Knowing, then, as I do, how to explain these things in detail, I deem it right at present to quote the words themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:52
verses.text: But since the expressions themselves urge us to speak of them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:53
verses.text: I shall not omit to do so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:54
verses.text: For these are truly divine and glorious things, and things well calculated to benefit the soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:55
verses.text: The prophet, in using the expression, a lion's whelp, means him who sprang from Judah and David according to the flesh, who was not made indeed of the seed of David, but was conceived by the (power of the) Holy Ghost, and came forth from the holy shoot of earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:56
verses.text: For Isaiah says, "There shall come forth a rod out of the root of Jesse, and a flower shall grow up out of it".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:57
verses.text: That which is called by Isaiah a flower, Jacob calls a shoot.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:58
verses.text: For first he shot forth, and then he flourished in the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:59
verses.text: And the expression, "he stooped down, he couched as a lion, and as a lion's whelp," refers to the three days' sleep (death, couching) of Christ; as also Isaiah says, "How is faithful Sion become an harlot! it was full of judgment; in which righteousness lodged (couched); but now murderers".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:60
verses.text: And David says to the same effect, "I laid me down (couched) and slept; I awaked: for the Lord will sustain me;" in which words he points to the fact of his sleep and rising again.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:61
verses.text: And Jacob says, "Who shall rouse him up?" And that is just what David and Paul both refer to, as when Paul says, "and God the Father, who raised Him from the dead".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:62
verses.text: And in saying, "A ruler shall not depart from Judah, nor a leader from his thighs, until he come for whom it is reserved; and he shall be the expectation of the nations," he referred the fulfilment (of that prophecy) to Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:63
verses.text: For He is our expectation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:64
verses.text: For we expect Him, (and) by faith we behold Him as He comes from heaven with power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:65
verses.text: "Binding his ass to a vine:" that means that He unites His people of the circumcision with His own calling (vocation).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:66
verses.text: For He was the vine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:67
verses.text: "And his ass's colt to the vine-tendril:" that denotes the people of the Gentiles, as He calls the circumcision and the uncircumcision unto one faith.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:68
verses.text: "He shall wash his garment in wine," that is, according to that voice of His Father which came down by the Holy Ghost at the Jordan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:69
verses.text: "And his clothes in the blood of the grape".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:70
verses.text: In the blood of what grape, then, but just His own flesh, which hung upon the tree like a cluster of grapes?—from whose side also flowed two streams, of blood and water, in which the nations are washed and purified, which (nations) He may be supposed to have as a robe about Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:71
verses.text: "His eyes gladsome with wine".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:72
verses.text: And what are the eyes of Christ but the blessed prophets, who foresaw in the Spirit, and announced beforehand, the sufferings that were to befall Him, and rejoiced in seeing Him in power with spiritual eyes, being furnished (for their vocation) by the word Himself and His grace?.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:73
verses.text: And in saying, "And his teeth (shall be) whiter than milk," he referred to the commandments that proceed from the holy mouth of Christ, and which are pure (purify) as milk.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:74
verses.text: Thus did the Scriptures preach before-time of this lion and lion's whelp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:75
verses.text: And in like manner also we find it written regarding Antichrist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:76
verses.text: For Moses speaks thus: "Dan is a lion's whelp, and he shall leap from Bashan".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:77
verses.text: But that no one may err by supposing that this is said of the Saviour, let him attend carefully to the matter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:78
verses.text: "Dan," he says, "is a lion's whelp;" and in naming the tribe of Dan, he declared clearly the tribe from which Antichrist is destined to spring.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:79
verses.text: For as Christ springs from the tribe of Judah, so Antichrist is to spring from the tribe of Dan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:80
verses.text: And that the case stands thus, we see also from the words of Jacob:  "Let Dan be a serpent, lying upon the ground, biting the horse's heel".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:81
verses.text: What, then, is meant by the serpent but Antichrist, that deceiver who is mentioned in Genesis, who deceived Eve and supplanted Adam (πτερνίσας, bruised Adam's heel)? But since it is necessary to prove this assertion by sufficient testimony, we shall not shrink from the task.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:82
verses.text: That it is in reality out of the tribe of Dan, then, that that tyrant and king, that dread judge, that son of the devil, is destined to spring and arise, the prophet testifies when he says, "Dan shall judge his people, as (he is) also one tribe in Israel".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:83
verses.text: But some one may say that this refers to Samson, who sprang from the tribe of Dan, and judged the people twenty years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:84
verses.text: Well, the prophecy had its partial fulfilment in Samson, but its complete fulfilment is reserved for Antichrist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:85
verses.text: For Jeremiah also speaks to this effect: "From Dan we are to hear the sound of the swiftness of his horses: the whole land trembled at the sound of the neighing, of the driving of his horses".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:86
verses.text: And another prophet says:  "He shall gather together all his strength, from the east even to the west.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:87
verses.text: They whom he calls, and they whom he calls not, shall go with him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:88
verses.text: He shall make the sea white with the sails of his ships, and the plain black with the shields of his armaments.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:89
verses.text: And whosoever shall oppose him in war shall fall by the sword".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:90
verses.text: That these things, then, are said of no one else but that tyrant, and shameless one, and adversary of God, we shall show in what follows.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:91
verses.text: But Isaiah also speaks thus:  "And it shall come to pass, that when the Lord hath performed His whole work upon Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, He will punish (visit) the stout mind, the king of Assyria, and the greatness (height) of the glory of his eyes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:92
verses.text: For he said, By my strength will I do it, and by the wisdom of my understanding I will remove the bounds of the peoples, and will rob them of their strength: and I will make the inhabited cities tremble, and will gather the whole world in my hand like a nest, and I will lift it up like eggs that are left.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:93
verses.text: And there is no one that shall escape or gainsay me, and open the mouth and chatter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:94
verses.text: Shall the axe boast itself without him that heweth therewith? or shall the saw magnify itself without him that shaketh (draweth) it? As if one should raise a rod or a staff, and the staff should lift itself up: and not thus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:95
verses.text: But the Lord shall send dishonour unto thy honour; and into thy glory a burning fire shall burn.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:96
verses.text: And the light of Israel shall be a fire, and shall sanctify him in flame, and shall consume the forest like grass".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:97
verses.text: And again he says in another place: "How hath the exactor ceased, and how hath the oppressor ceased! God hath broken the yoke of the rulers of sinners, He who smote the people in wrath, and with an incurable stroke: He that strikes the people with an incurable stroke, which He did not spare.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:98
verses.text: He ceased (rested) confidently: the whole earth shouts with rejoicing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:99
verses.text: The trees of Lebanon rejoiced at thee, and the cedar of Lebanon, (saying), Since thou art laid down, no feller is come up against us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:100
verses.text: Hell from beneath is moved at meeting thee: all the mighty ones, the rulers of the earth, are gathered together—the lords from their thrones.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:101
verses.text: All the kings of the nations, all they shall answer together, and shall say, And thou, too, art taken as we; and thou art reckoned among us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:102
verses.text: Thy pomp is brought down to earth, thy great rejoicing: they will spread decay under thee; and the worm shall be thy covering.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:103
verses.text: How art thou fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! He is cast down to the ground who sends off to all the nations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:104
verses.text: And thou didst say in thy mind, I will ascend into heaven, I will set my throne above the stars of heaven: I will sit down upon the lofty mountains towards the north: I will ascend above the clouds: I will be like the Most High.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:105
verses.text: Yet now thou shalt be brought down to hell, and to the foundations of the earth! They that see thee shall wonder at thee, and shall say, This is the man that excited the earth, that did shake kings, that made the whole world a wilderness, and destroyed the cities, that released not those in prison.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:106
verses.text: All the kings of the earth did lie in honour, every one in his own house; but thou shalt be cast out on the mountains like a loathsome carcase, with many who fall, pierced through with the sword, and going down to hell.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:107
verses.text: As a garment stained with blood is not pure, so neither shalt thou be comely (or clean); because thou hast destroyed my land, and slain my people.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:108
verses.text: Thou shalt not abide, enduring for ever, a wicked seed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:109
verses.text: Prepare thy children for slaughter, for the sins of thy father, that they rise not, neither possess my land".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:110
verses.text: Ezekiel also speaks of him to the same effect, thus: "Thus saith the Lord God, Because thine heart is lifted up, and thou hast said, I am God, I sit in the seat of God, in the midst of the sea; yet art thou a man, and not God, (though) thou hast set thine heart as the heart of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:111
verses.text: Art thou wiser than Daniel? Have the wise not instructed thee in their wisdom?  With thy wisdom or with thine understanding hast thou gotten thee power, and gold and silver in thy treasures? By thy great wisdom and by thy traffic hast thou increased thy power? Thy heart is lifted up in thy power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:112
verses.text: Therefore thus saith the Lord God: Because thou hast set thine heart as the heart of God:  behold, therefore I will bring strangers upon thee, plagues from the nations: and they shall draw their swords against thee, and against the beauty of thy wisdom; and they shall level thy beauty to destruction; and they shall bring thee down; and thou shalt die by the death of the wounded in the midst of the sea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:113
verses.text: Wilt thou yet say before them that slay thee, I am God? But thou art a man, and no God, in the hand of them that wound thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:114
verses.text: Thou shalt die the deaths of the uncircumcised by the hand of strangers: for I have spoken it, saith the Lord".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:115
verses.text: These words then being thus presented, let us observe somewhat in detail what Daniel says in his visions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:116
verses.text: For in distinguishing the kingdoms that are to rise after these things, he showed also the coming of Antichrist in the last times, and the consummation of the whole world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:117
verses.text: In expounding the vision of Nebuchadnezzar, then, he speaks thus: "Thou, O king, sawest, and behold a great image standing before thy face:  the head of which was of fine gold, its arms and shoulders of silver, its belly and its thighs of brass, and its legs of iron, (and) its feet part of iron and part of clay.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:118
verses.text: Thou sawest, then, till that a stone was cut out without hands, and smote the image upon the feet that were of iron and clay, and brake them to an end.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:119
verses.text: Then were the clay, the iron, the brass, the silver, (and) the gold broken, and became like the chaff from the summer threshing-floor; and the strength (fulness) of the wind carried them away, and there was no place found for them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:120
verses.text: And the stone that smote the image became a great mountain, and filled the whole earth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:121
verses.text: Now if we set Daniel's own visions also side by side with this, we shall have one exposition to give of the two together, and shall (be able to) show how concordant with each other they are, and how true.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:122
verses.text: For he speaks thus: "I Daniel saw, and behold the four winds of the heaven strove upon the great sea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:123
verses.text: And four great beasts came up from the sea, diverse one from another.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:124
verses.text: The first (was) like a lioness, and had wings as of an eagle.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:125
verses.text: I beheld till the wings thereof were plucked, and it was lifted up from the earth, and made stand upon the feet as a man, and a man's heart was given to it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:126
verses.text: And behold a second beast like to a bear, and it was made stand on one part, and it had three ribs in the mouth of it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:127
verses.text: I beheld, and lo a beast like a leopard, and it had upon the back of it four wings of a fowl, and the beast had four heads.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:128
verses.text: After this I saw, and behold a fourth beast, dreadful and terrible, and strong exceedingly; it had iron teeth and claws of brass, which devoured and brake in pieces, and it stamped the residue with the feet of it; and it was diverse from all the beasts that were before it, and it had ten horns.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:129
verses.text: I considered its horns, and behold there came up among them another little horn, and before it there were three of the first horns plucked up by the roots; and behold in this horn were eyes like the eyes of man, and a mouth speaking great things".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:130
verses.text: "I beheld till the thrones were set, and the Ancient of days did sit: and His garment was white as snow, and the hair of His head like pure wool: His throne was a flame of fire, His wheels were a burning fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:131
verses.text: A stream of fire flowed before Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:132
verses.text: Thousand thousands ministered unto Him, and ten thousand times ten thousand stood around Him: the judgment was set, and the books were opened.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:133
verses.text: I beheld then, because of the voice of the great words which the horn spake, till the beast was slain and perished, and his body given to the burning of fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:134
verses.text: And the dominion of the other beasts was taken away".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:135
verses.text: "I saw in the night vision, and, behold, one like the Son of man was coming with the clouds of heaven, and came to the Ancient of days, and was brought near before Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:136
verses.text: And there was given Him dominion, and honour, and the kingdom; and all peoples, tribes, and tongues shall serve Him: His dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shall not pass away, and His kingdom shall not be destroyed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:137
verses.text: Now since these things, spoken as they are with a mystical meaning, may seem to some hard to understand, we shall keep back nothing fitted to impart an intelligent apprehension of them to those who are possessed of a sound mind.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:138
verses.text: He said, then, that a "lioness came up from the sea," and by that he meant the kingdom of the Babylonians in the world, which also was the head of gold on the image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:139
verses.text: In saying that "it had wings as of an eagle," he meant that Nebuchadnezzar the king was lifted up and was exalted against God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:140
verses.text: Then he says, "the wings thereof were plucked," that is to say, his glory was destroyed; for he was driven out of his kingdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:141
verses.text: And the words, "a man's heart was given to it, and it was made stand upon the feet as a man," refer to the fact that he repented and recognised himself to be only a man, and gave the glory to God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:142
verses.text: Then, after the lioness, he sees a "second beast like a bear," and that denoted the Persians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:143
verses.text: For after the Babylonians, the Persians held the sovereign power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:144
verses.text: And in saying that there were "three ribs in the mouth of it," he pointed to three nations, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:145
verses.text: , the Persians, and the Medes, and the Babylonians; which were also represented on the image by the silver after the gold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:146
verses.text: Then (there was) "the third beast, a leopard," which meant the Greeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:147
verses.text: For after the Persians, Alexander of Macedon obtained the sovereign power on subverting Darius, as is also shown by the brass on the image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:148
verses.text: And in saying that it had "four wings of a fowl," he taught us most clearly how the kingdom of Alexander was partitioned.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:149
verses.text: For in speaking of "four heads," he made mention of four kings, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:150
verses.text: , those who arose out of that (kingdom).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:151
verses.text: For Alexander, when dying, partitioned out his kingdom into four divisions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:152
verses.text: Then he says: "A fourth beast, dreadful and terrible; it had iron teeth and claws of brass".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:153
verses.text: And who are these but the Romans? which (kingdom) is meant by the iron—the kingdom which is now established; for the legs of that (image) were of iron.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:154
verses.text: And after this, what remains, beloved, but the toes of the feet of the image, in which part is iron and part clay, mixed together? And mystically by the toes of the feet he meant the kings who are to arise from among them; as Daniel also says (in the words), "I considered the beast, and lo there were ten horns behind it, among which shall rise another (horn), an offshoot, and shall pluck up by the roots the three (that were) before it".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:155
verses.text: And under this was signified none other than Antichrist, who is also himself to raise the kingdom of the Jews.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:156
verses.text: He says that three horns are plucked up by the root by him, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:157
verses.text: , the three kings of Egypt, and Libya, and Ethiopia, whom he cuts off in the array of battle.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:158
verses.text: And he, after gaining terrible power over all, being nevertheless a tyrant, shall stir up tribulation and persecution against men, exalting himself against them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:159
verses.text: For Daniel says: "I considered the horn, and behold that horn made war with the saints, and prevailed against them, till the beast was slain and perished, and its body was given to the burning of fire".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:160
verses.text: After a little space the stone will come from heaven which smites the image and breaks it in pieces, and subverts all the kingdoms, and gives the kingdom to the saints of the Most High.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:161
verses.text: This is the stone which becomes a great mountain, and fills the whole earth, of which Daniel says: "I saw in the night visions, and behold one like the Son of man came with the clouds of heaven, and came to the Ancient of days, and was brought near before Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:162
verses.text: And there was given Him dominion, and glory, and a kingdom; and all peoples, tribes, and languages shall serve Him: and His dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shall not pass away, and His kingdom shall not be destroyed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:163
verses.text: He showed all power given by the Father to the Son, who is ordained Lord of things in heaven, and things on earth, and things under the earth, and Judge of all: of things in heaven, because He was born, the Word of God, before all (ages); and of things on earth, because He became man in the midst of men, to re-create our Adam through Himself; and of things under the earth, because He was also reckoned among the dead, preaching the Gospel to the souls of the saints, (and) by death overcoming death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:164
verses.text: As these things, then, are in the future, and as the ten toes of the image are equivalent to (so many) democracies, and the ten horns of the fourth beast are distributed over ten kingdoms, let us look at the subject a little more closely, and consider these matters as in the clear light of a personal survey.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:165
verses.text: The golden head of the image and the lioness denoted the Babylonians; the shoulders and arms of silver, and the bear, represented the Persians and Medes; the belly and thighs of brass, and the leopard, meant the Greeks, who held the sovereignty from Alexander's time; the legs of iron, and the beast dreadful and terrible, expressed the Romans, who hold the sovereignty at present; the toes of the feet which were part clay and part iron, and the ten horns, were emblems of the kingdoms that are yet to rise; the other little horn that grows up among them meant the Antichrist in their midst; the stone that smites the earth and brings judgment upon the world was Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:166
verses.text: These things, beloved, we impart to you with fear, and yet readily, on account of the love of Christ, which surpasseth all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:167
verses.text: For if the blessed prophets who preceded us did not choose to proclaim these things, though they knew them, openly and boldly, lest they should disquiet the souls of men, but recounted them mystically in parables and dark sayings, speaking thus, "Here is the mind which hath wisdom," how much greater risk shall we run in venturing to declare openly things spoken by them in obscure terms! Let us look, therefore, at the things which are to befall this unclean harlot in the last days; and (let us consider) what and what manner of tribulation is destined to visit her in the wrath of God before the judgment as an earnest of her doom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:168
verses.text: Come, then, O blessed Isaiah; arise, tell us clearly what thou didst prophesy with respect to the mighty Babylon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:169
verses.text: For thou didst speak also of Jerusalem, and thy word is accomplished.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:170
verses.text: For thou didst speak boldly and openly:  "Your country is desolate, your cities are burned with fire; your land, strangers devour it in your presence, and it is desolate as overthrown by many strangers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:171
verses.text: The daughter of Sion shall be left as a cottage in a vineyard, and as a lodge in a garden of cucumbers, as a besieged city".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:172
verses.text: What then? Are not these things come to pass? Are not the things announced by thee fulfilled? Is not their country, Judea, desolate? Is not the holy place burned with fire? Are not their walls cast down? Are not their cities destroyed? Their land, do not strangers devour it? Do not the Romans rule the country?  And indeed these impious people hated thee, and did saw thee asunder, and they crucified Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:173
verses.text: Thou art dead in the world, but thou livest in Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:174
verses.text: Which of you, then, shall I esteem more than thee? Yet Jeremiah, too, is stoned.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:175
verses.text: But if I should esteem Jeremiah most, yet Daniel too has his testimony.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:176
verses.text: Daniel, I commend thee above all; yet John too gives no false witness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:177
verses.text: With how many mouths and tongues would I praise you; or rather the Word who spake in you! Ye died with Christ; and ye will live with Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:178
verses.text: Hear ye, and rejoice; behold the things announced by you have been fulfilled in their time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:179
verses.text: For ye saw these things yourselves first, and then ye proclaimed them to all generations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:180
verses.text: Ye ministered the oracles of God to all generations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:181
verses.text: Ye prophets were called, that ye might be able to save all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:182
verses.text: For then is one a prophet indeed, when, having announced beforetime things about to be, he can afterwards show that they have actually happened.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:183
verses.text: Ye were the disciples of a good Master.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:184
verses.text: These words I address to you as if alive, and with propriety.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:185
verses.text: For ye hold already the crown of life and immortality which is laid up for you in heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:186
verses.text: Speak with me, O blessed Daniel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:187
verses.text: Give me full assurance, I beseech thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:188
verses.text: Thou dost prophesy concerning the lioness in Babylon; for thou wast a captive there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:189
verses.text: Thou hast unfolded the future regarding the bear; for thou wast still in the world, and didst see the things come to pass.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:190
verses.text: Then thou speakest to me of the leopard; and whence canst thou know this, for thou art already gone to thy rest? Who instructed thee to announce these things, but He who formed thee in (from) thy mother's womb? That is God, thou sayest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:191
verses.text: Thou hast spoken indeed, and that not falsely.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:192
verses.text: The leopard has arisen; the he-goat is come; he hath smitten the ram; he hath broken his horns in pieces; he hath stamped upon him with his feet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:193
verses.text: He has been exalted by his fall; (the) four horns have come up from under that one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:194
verses.text: Rejoice, blessed Daniel! thou hast not been in error: all these things have come to pass.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:195
verses.text: After this again thou hast told me of the beast dreadful and terrible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:196
verses.text: "It had iron teeth and claws of brass: it devoured and brake in pieces, and stamped the residue with the feet of it".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:197
verses.text: Already the iron rules; already it subdues and breaks all in pieces; already it brings all the unwilling into subjection; already we see these things ourselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:198
verses.text: Now we glorify God, being instructed by thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:199
verses.text: But as the task before us was to speak of the harlot, be thou with us, O blessed Isaiah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:200
verses.text: Let us mark what thou sayest about Babylon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:201
verses.text: "Come down, sit upon the ground, O virgin daughter of Babylon; sit, O daughter of the Chaldeans; thou shalt no longer be called tender and delicate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:202
verses.text: Take the millstone, grind meal, draw aside thy veil, shave the grey hairs, make bare the legs, pass over the rivers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:203
verses.text: Thy shame shall be uncovered, thy reproach shall be seen: I will take justice of thee, I will no more give thee over to men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:204
verses.text: As for thy Redeemer, (He is) the Lord of hosts, the Holy One of Israel is his name.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:205
verses.text: Sit thou in compunction, get thee into darkness, O daughter of the Chaldeans: thou shalt no longer be called the strength of the kingdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:206
verses.text: "I was wroth with my people; I have polluted mine inheritance, I have given them into thine hand: and thou didst show them no mercy; but upon the ancient (the elders) thou hast very heavily laid thy yoke.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:207
verses.text: And thou saidst, I shall be a princess for ever: thou didst not lay these things to thy heart, neither didst remember thy latter end.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:208
verses.text: Therefore hear now this, thou that art delicate; that sittest, that art confident, that sayest in thine heart, I am, and there is none else; I shall not sit as a widow, neither shall I know the loss of children.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:209
verses.text: But now these two things shall come upon thee in one day, widowhood and the loss of children: they shall come upon thee suddenly in thy sorcery, in the strength of thine enchantments mightily, in the hope of thy fornication.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:210
verses.text: For thou hast said, I am, and there is none else.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:211
verses.text: And thy fornication shall be thy shame, because thou hast said in thy heart, I am.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:212
verses.text: And destruction shall come upon thee, and thou shalt not know it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:213
verses.text: (And there shall be) a pit, and thou shalt fall into it; and misery shall fall upon thee, and thou shalt not be able to be made clean; and destruction shall come upon thee, and thou shalt not know it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:214
verses.text: Stand now with thy enchantments, and with the multitude of thy sorceries, which thou hast learned from thy youth; if so be thou shalt be able to be profited.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:215
verses.text: Thou art wearied in thy counsels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:216
verses.text: Let the astrologers of the heavens stand and save thee; let the star-gazers announce to thee what shall come upon thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:217
verses.text: Behold, they shall all be as sticks for the fire; so shall they be burned, and they shall not deliver their soul from the flame.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:218
verses.text: Because thou hast coals of fire, sit upon them; so shall it be for thy help.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:219
verses.text: Thou art wearied with change from thy youth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:220
verses.text: Man has gone astray (each one) by himself; and there shall be no salvation for thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:221
verses.text: These things does Isaiah prophesy for thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:222
verses.text: Let us see now whether John has spoken to the same effect.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:223
verses.text: For he sees, when in the isle Patmos, a revelation of awful mysteries, which he recounts freely, and makes known to others.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:224
verses.text: Tell me, blessed John, apostle and disciple of the Lord, what didst thou see and hear concerning Babylon? Arise, and speak; for it sent thee also into banishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:225
verses.text: "And there came one of the seven angels which had the seven vials, and talked with me, saying unto me, Come hither; I will show unto thee the judgment of the great whore that sitteth upon many waters; with whom the kings of the earth have committed fornication, and the inhabitants of the earth have been made drunk with the wine of her fornication.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:226
verses.text: And he carried me away in the spirit into the wilderness: and I saw a woman sit upon a scarlet-coloured beast, full of names of blasphemy, having seven heads and ten horns.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:227
verses.text: And the woman was arrayed in purple and scarlet colour, and decked with gold, and precious stone, and pearls, having a golden cup in her hand, full of abominations and filthiness of the fornication of the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:228
verses.text: Upon her forehead was a name written, Mystery, Babylon the Great, the Mother of Harlots and Abominations of the Earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:229
verses.text: "And I saw the woman drunken with the blood of the saints, and with the blood of the martyrs of Jesus: and when I saw her, I wondered with great admiration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:230
verses.text: And the angel said unto me, Wherefore didst thou marvel? I will tell thee the mystery of the woman, and of the beast that carrieth her, which hath the seven heads and the ten horns.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:231
verses.text: The beast that thou sawest was, and is not; and shall ascend out of the bottomless pit, and go into perdition: and they that dwell on the earth shall wonder (whose name was not written in the book of life from the foundation of the world) when they behold the beast that was, and is not, and yet shall be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:232
verses.text: "And here is the mind that has wisdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:233
verses.text: The seven heads are seven mountains, on which the woman sitteth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:234
verses.text: And there are seven kings: five are fallen, and one is, and the other is not yet come; and when he cometh, he must continue a short space.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:235
verses.text: And the beast that was and is not, (even he is the eighth,) and is of the seven, and goeth into perdition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:236
verses.text: And the ten horns which thou sawest are ten kings, which have received no kingdom as yet; but receive power as kings one hour with the beast.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:237
verses.text: These have one mind, and shall give their power and strength unto the beast.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:238
verses.text: These shall make war with the Lamb, and the Lamb shall overcome them: for he is Lord of lords, and King of kings; and they that are with Him are called, and chosen, and faithful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:239
verses.text: "And he saith to me, The waters which thou sawest, where the whore sitteth, are peoples, and multitudes, and nations, and tongues.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:240
verses.text: And the ten horns which thou sawest, and the beast, these shall hate the whore, and shall make her desolate and naked, and shall eat her flesh, and burn her with fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:241
verses.text: For God hath put in their hearts to fulfil His will, and to agree, and give their kingdom unto the beast, until the words of God shall be fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:242
verses.text: And the woman which thou sawest is that great city, which reigneth over the kings of the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:243
verses.text: "After these things I saw another angel come down from heaven, having great power; and the earth was lightened with his glory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:244
verses.text: And he cried mightily with a strong voice, saying, Babylon the great is fallen, is fallen, and is become the habitation of devils, and the hold of every foul spirit, and a cage of every unclean and hateful bird.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:245
verses.text: For all nations have drunk of the wine of the wrath of her fornication, and the kings of the earth have committed fornication with her, and the merchants of the earth are waxed rich through the abundance of her delicacies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:246
verses.text: And I heard another voice from heaven, saying, Come out of her, my people, that ye be not partakers of her sins, and that ye receive not of her plagues:  for her sins did cleave even unto heaven, and God hath remembered her iniquities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:247
verses.text: "Reward her even as she rewarded (you), and double unto her double, according to her works: in the cup which she hath filled, fill to her double.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:248
verses.text: How much she hath glorified herself, and lived deliciously, so much torment and sorrow give her: for she saith in her heart, I sit a queen, and am no widow, and shall see no sorrow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:249
verses.text: Therefore shall her plagues come in one day, death, and mourning, and famine; and she shall be utterly burned with fire: for strong is the Lord God who judgeth her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:250
verses.text: And the kings of the earth, who have committed fornication, and lived deliciously with her, shall bewail her, and lament for her, when they shall see the smoke of her burning, standing afar off for the fear of her torment, saying, Alas, alas! that great city Babylon, that mighty city! for in one hour is thy judgment come.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:251
verses.text: And the merchants of the earth shall weep and mourn over her; for no man shall buy their merchandise any more.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:252
verses.text: The merchandise of gold, and silver, and precious stones, and of pearls, and fine linen, and purple, and silk, and scarlet, and all thyine wood, and all manner vessels of ivory, and all manner vessels of most precious wood, and of brass, and iron, and marble, and cinnamon, and spices, and odours, and ointments, and frankincense, and wine, and oil, and fine flour, and wheat, and beasts, and sheep, and goats, and horses, and chariots, and slaves (bodies), and souls of men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:253
verses.text: And the fruits that thy soul lusted after are departed from thee, and all things which were dainty and goodly have perished from thee, and thou shalt find them no more at all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:254
verses.text: The merchants of these things, which were made rich by her, shall stand afar off for the fear of her torment, weeping and wailing, and saying, Alas, alas! that great city, that was clothed in fine linen, and purple, and scarlet, and decked with gold, and precious stones, and pearls! for in one hour so great riches is come to nought.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:255
verses.text: And every shipmaster, and all the company in ships, and sailors, and as many as trade by sea, stood afar off, and cried, when they saw the smoke of her burning, saying, What city is like unto this great city? And they cast dust on their heads, and cried, weeping and wailing, saying, Alas, alas! that great city, wherein were made rich all that had ships in the sea by reason of her fatness! for in one hour is she made desolate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:256
verses.text: "Rejoice over her, thou heaven, and ye angels, and apostles, and prophets; for God hath avenged you on her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:257
verses.text: And a mighty angel took up a stone like a great millstone, and cast it into the sea, saying, Thus with violence shall that great city Babylon be thrown down, and shall be found no more at all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:258
verses.text: And the voice of harpers and musicians, and of pipers and trumpeters, shall be heard no more at all in thee; and no craftsman, of whatsoever craft he be, shall be found any more in thee; and the sound of a millstone shall be heard no more at all in thee; and the light of a candle shall shine no more at all in thee; and the voice of the bridegroom and of the bride shall be heard no more at all in thee: for thy merchants were the great men of the earth; for by thy sorceries were all nations deceived.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:259
verses.text: And in her was found the blood of prophets and of saints, and of all that were slain upon the earth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:260
verses.text: With respect, then, to the particular judgment in the torments that are to come upon it in the last times by the hand of the tyrants who shall arise then, the clearest statement has been given in these passages.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:261
verses.text: But it becomes us further diligently to examine and set forth the period at which these things shall come to pass, and how the little horn shall spring up in their midst.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:262
verses.text: For when the legs of iron have issued in the feet and toes, according to the similitude of the image and that of the terrible beast, as has been shown in the above, (then shall be the time) when the iron and the clay shall be mingled together.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:263
verses.text: Now Daniel will set forth this subject to us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:264
verses.text: For he says, "And one week will make a covenant with many, and it shall be that in the midst (half) of the week my sacrifice and oblation shall cease".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:265
verses.text: By one week, therefore, he meant the last week which is to be at the end of the whole world of which week the two prophets Enoch and Elias will take up the half.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:266
verses.text: For they will preach ,  days clothed in sackcloth, proclaiming repentance to the people and to all the nations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:267
verses.text: For as two advents of our Lord and Saviour are indicated in the Scriptures, the one being His first advent in the flesh, which took place without honour by reason of His being set at nought, as Isaiah spake of Him aforetime, saying, "We saw Him, and He had no form nor comeliness, but His form was despised (and) rejected (lit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:268
verses.text: = deficient) above all men; a man smitten and familiar with bearing infirmity, (for His face was turned away); He was despised, and esteemed not".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:269
verses.text: But His second advent is announced as glorious, when He shall come from heaven with the host of angels, and the glory of His Father, as the prophet saith, "Ye shall see the King in glory;" and, "I saw one like the Son of man coming with the clouds of heaven; and he came to the Ancient of days, and he was brought to Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:270
verses.text: And there were given Him dominion, and honour, and glory, and the kingdom; all tribes and languages shall serve Him: His dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shall not pass away".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:271
verses.text: Thus also two forerunners were indicated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:272
verses.text: The first was John the son of Zacharias, who appeared in all things a forerunner and herald of our Saviour, preaching of the heavenly light that had appeared in the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:273
verses.text: He first fulfilled the course of forerunner, and that from his mother's womb, being conceived by Elisabeth, in order that to those, too, who are children from their mother's womb he might declare the new birth that was to take place for their sakes by the Holy Ghost and the Virgin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:274
verses.text: He, on hearing the salutation addressed to Elisabeth, leaped with joy in his mother's womb, recognising God the Word conceived in the womb of the Virgin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:275
verses.text: Thereafter he came forward preaching in the wilderness, proclaiming the baptism of repentance to the people, (and thus) announcing prophetically salvation to the nations living in the wilderness of the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:276
verses.text: After this, at the Jordan, seeing the Saviour with his own eye, he points Him out, and says, "Behold the Lamb of God, that taketh away the sin of the world!" He also first preached to those in Hades, becoming a forerunner there when he was put to death by Herod, that there too he might intimate that the Saviour would descend to ransom the souls of the saints from the hand of death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:277
verses.text: But since the Saviour was the beginning of the resurrection of all men, it was meet that the Lord alone should rise from the dead, by whom too the judgment is to enter for the whole world, that they who have wrestled worthily may be also crowned worthily by Him, by the illustrious Arbiter, to wit, who Himself first accomplished the course, and was received into the heavens, and was set down on the right hand of God the Father, and is to be manifested again at the end of the world as Judge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:278
verses.text: It is a matter of course that His forerunners must appear first, as He says by Malachi and the angel, "I will send to you Elias the Tishbite before the day of the Lord, the great and notable day, comes; and he shall turn the hearts of the fathers to the children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just, lest I come and smite the earth utterly".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:279
verses.text: These, then, shall come and proclaim the manifestation of Christ that is to be from heaven; and they shall also perform signs and wonders, in order that men may be put to shame and turned to repentance for their surpassing wickedness and impiety.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:280
verses.text: For John says, "And I will give power unto my two witnesses, and they shall prophesy a thousand two hundred and threescore days, clothed in sackcloth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:281
verses.text: That is the half of the week whereof Daniel spake.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:282
verses.text: "These are the two olive trees and the two candlesticks standing before the Lord of the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:283
verses.text: And if any man will hurt them, fire will proceed out of their mouth, and devour their enemies; and if any man will hurt them, he must in this manner be killed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:284
verses.text: These have power to shut heaven, that it rain not in the days of their prophecy; and have power over waters, to turn them to blood, and to smite the earth with all plagues as often as they will.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:285
verses.text: And when they shall have finished their course and their testimony," what saith the prophet? "the beast that ascendeth out of the bottomless pit shall make war against them, and shall overcome them, and kill them," because they will not give glory to Antichrist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:286
verses.text: For this is meant by the little horn that grows up.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:287
verses.text: He, being now elated in heart, begins to exalt himself, and to glorify himself as God, persecuting the saints and blaspheming Christ, even as Daniel says, "I considered the horn, and, behold, in the horn were eyes like the eyes of man, and a mouth speaking great things; and he opened his mouth to blaspheme God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:288
verses.text: And that born made war against the saints, and prevailed against them until the beast was slain, and perished, and his body was given to be burned".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:289
verses.text: But as it is incumbent on us to discuss this matter of the beast more exactly, and in particular the question how the Holy Spirit has also mystically indicated his name by means of a number, we shall proceed to state more clearly what bears upon him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:290
verses.text: John then speaks thus: "And I beheld another beast coming up out of the earth; and he had two horns, like a lamb, and he spake as a dragon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:291
verses.text: And he exercised all the power of the first beast before him; and he made the earth and them which dwell therein to worship the first beast, whose deadly wound was healed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:292
verses.text: And he did great wonders, so that he maketh fire come down from heaven on the earth in the sight of men, and deceiveth them that dwell on the earth by means of those miracles which he had power to do in the sight of the beast, saying to them that dwell on the earth, that they should make an image to the beast which had the wound by a sword and did live.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:293
verses.text: And he had power to give life unto the image of the beast, that the image of the beast should both speak, and cause that as many as would not worship the image of the beast should be killed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:294
verses.text: And he caused all, both small and great, rich and poor, free and bond, to receive a mark in their right hand or in their forehead; and that no man might buy or sell, save he that had the mark, the name of the beast, or the number of his name.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:295
verses.text: Here is wisdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:296
verses.text: Let him that hath understanding count the number of the beast; for if is the number of a man, and his number is six hundred threescore and six".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:297
verses.text: By the beast, then, coming up out of the earth, he means the kingdom of Antichrist; and by the two horns he means him and the false prophet after him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:298
verses.text: And in speaking of "the horns being like a lamb," he means that he will make himself like the Son of God, and set himself forward as king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:299
verses.text: And the terms, "he spake like a dragon," mean that he is a deceiver, and not truthful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:300
verses.text: And the words, "he exercised all the power of the first beast before him, and caused the earth and them which dwell therein to worship the first beast, whose deadly wound was healed," signify that, after the manner of the law of Augustus, by whom the empire of Rome was established, he too will rule and govern, sanctioning everything by it, and taking greater glory to himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:301
verses.text: For this is the fourth beast, whose head was wounded and healed again, in its being broken up or even dishonoured, and partitioned into four crowns; and he then (Antichrist) shall with knavish skill heal it, as it were, and restore it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:302
verses.text: For this is what is meant by the prophet when he says, "He will give life unto the image, and the image of the beast will speak".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:303
verses.text: For he will act with vigour again, and prove strong by reason of the laws established by him; and he will cause all those who will not worship the image of the beast to be put to death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:304
