verses.text: Here the faith and the patience of the saints will appear, for he says: "And he will cause all, both small and great, rich and poor, free and bond, to receive a mark in their right hand or in their forehead; that no man might buy or sell, save he that had the mark, the name of the beast, or the number of his name".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:305
verses.text: For, being full of guile, and exalting himself against the servants of God, with the wish to afflict them and persecute them out of the world, because they give not glory to him, he will order incense-pans to be set up by all everywhere, that no man among the saints may be able to buy or sell without first sacrificing; for this is what is meant by the mark received upon the right hand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:306
verses.text: And the word—"in their forehead"—indicates that all are crowned, and put on a crown of fire, and not of life, but of death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:307
verses.text: For in this wise, too, did Antiochus Epiphanes the king of Syria, the descendant of Alexander of Macedon, devise measures against the Jews.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:308
verses.text: He, too, in the exaltation of his heart, issued a decree in those times, that "all should set up shrines before their doors, and sacrifice, and that they should march in procession to the honour of Dionysus, waving chaplets of ivy;" and that those who refused obedience should be put to death by strangulation and torture.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:309
verses.text: But he also met his due recompense at the hand of the Lord, the righteous Judge and all-searching God; for he died eaten up of worms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:310
verses.text: And if one desires to inquire into that more accurately, he will find it recorded in the books of the Maccabees.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:311
verses.text: But now we shall speak of what is before us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:312
verses.text: For such measures will he, too, devise, seeking to afflict the saints in every way.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:313
verses.text: For the prophet and apostle says:  "Here is wisdom, Let him that hath understanding count the number of the beast; for it is the number of a man, and his number is six hundred threescore and six".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:314
verses.text: With respect to his name, it is not in our power to explain it exactly, as the blessed John understood it and was instructed about it, but only to give a conjectural account of it; for when he appears, the blessed one will show us what we seek to know.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:315
verses.text: Yet as far as our doubtful apprehension of the matter goes, we may speak.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:316
verses.text: Many names indeed we find, the letters of which are the equivalent of this number: such as, for instance, the word Titan, an ancient and notable name; or Evanthas, for it too makes up the same number; and many others which might be found.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:317
verses.text: But, as we have already said, the wound of the first beast was healed, and he (the second beast) was to make the image speak, that is to say, he should be powerful; and it is manifest to all that those who at present still hold the power are Latins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:318
verses.text: If, then, we take the name as the name of a single man, it becomes Latinus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:319
verses.text: Wherefore we ought neither to give it out as if this were certainly his name, nor again ignore the fact that he may not be otherwise designated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:320
verses.text: But having the mystery of God in our heart, we ought in fear to keep faithfully what has been told us by the blessed prophets, in order that when those things come to pass, we may be prepared for them, and not deceived.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:321
verses.text: For when the times advance, he too, of whom these thing are said, will be manifested.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:322
verses.text: But not to confine ourselves to these words and arguments alone, for the purpose of convincing those who love to study the oracles of God, we shall demonstrate the matter by many other proofs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:323
verses.text: For Daniel says, "And these shall escape out of his hand, even Edom, and Moab, and the chief of the children of Ammon".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:324
verses.text: Ammon and Moab are the children born to Lot by his daughters, and their race survives even now.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:325
verses.text: And Isaiah says: "And they shall fly in the boats of strangers, plundering the sea together, and (they shall spoil) them of the east: and they shall lay hands upon Moab first; and the children of Ammon shall first obey them".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:326
verses.text: In those times, then, he shall arise and meet them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:327
verses.text: And when he has overmastered three horns out of the ten in the array of war, and has rooted these out, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:328
verses.text: , Egypt, and Libya, and Ethiopia, and has got their spoils and trappings, and has brought the remaining horns which suffer into subjection, he will begin to be lifted up in heart, and to exalt himself against God as master of the whole world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:329
verses.text: And his first expedition will be against Tyre and Berytus, and the circumjacent territory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:330
verses.text: For by storming these cities first he will strike terror into the others, as Isaiah says, "Be thou ashamed, O Sidon; the sea hath spoken, even the strength of the sea hath spoken, saying, I travailed not, nor brought forth children; neither did I nurse up young men, nor bring up virgins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:331
verses.text: But when the report comes to Egypt, pain shall seize them for Tyre".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:332
verses.text: These things, then, shall be in the future, beloved; and when the three horns are cut off, he will begin to show himself as God, as Ezekiel has said aforetime:  "Because thy heart has been lifted up, and thou hast said, I am God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:333
verses.text: And to the like effect Isaiah says: "For thou hast said in thine heart, I will ascend into heaven, I will exalt my throne above the stars of heaven: I will be like the Most High.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:334
verses.text: Yet now thou shalt be brought down to hell (Hades), to the foundations of the earth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:335
verses.text: In like manner also Ezekiel: "Wilt thou yet say to those who slay thee, I am God? But thou (shalt be) a man, and no God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:336
verses.text: As his tribe, then, and his manifestation, and his destruction, have been set forth in these words, and as his name has also been indicated mystically, let us look also at his action.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:337
verses.text: For he will call together all the people to himself, out of every country of the dispersion, making them his own, as though they were his own children, and promising to restore their country, and establish again their kingdom and nation, in order that he may be worshipped by them as God, as the prophet says: "He will collect his whole kingdom, from the rising of the sun even to its setting: they whom he summons and they whom he does not summon shall march with him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:338
verses.text: And Jeremiah speaks of him thus in a parable: "The partridge cried, (and) gathered what he did not hatch, making himself riches without judgment: in the midst of his days they shall leave him, and at his end he shall be a fool".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:339
verses.text: It will not be detrimental, therefore, to the course of our present argument, if we explain the art of that creature, and show that the prophet has not spoken without a purpose in using the parable (or similitude) of the creature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:340
verses.text: For as the partridge is a vainglorious creature, when it sees near at hand the nest of another partridge with young in it, and with the parent-bird away on the wing in quest of food, it imitates the cry of the other bird, and calls the young to itself; and they, taking it to be their own parent, run to it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:341
verses.text: And it delights itself proudly in the alien pullets as in its own.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:342
verses.text: But when the real parent-bird returns, and calls them with its own familiar cry, the young recognise it, and forsake the deceiver, and betake themselves to the real parent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:343
verses.text: This thing, then, the prophet has adopted as a simile, applying it in a similar manner to Antichrist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:344
verses.text: For he will allure mankind to himself, wishing to gain possession of those who are not his own, and promising deliverance to all, while he is unable to save himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:345
verses.text: He then, having gathered to himself the unbelieving everywhere throughout the world, comes at their call to persecute the saints, their enemies and antagonists, as the apostle and evangelist says: "There was in a city a judge, which feared not God, neither regarded man: and there was a widow in that city, who came unto him, saying, Avenge me of mine adversary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:346
verses.text: And he would not for a while: but afterward he said within himself, Though I fear not God, nor regard man; yet because this widow troubleth me, I will avenge her".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:347
verses.text: By the unrighteous judge, who fears not God, neither regards man, he means without doubt Antichrist, as he is a son of the devil and a vessel of Satan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:348
verses.text: For when he has the power, he will begin to exalt himself against God, neither in truth fearing God, nor regarding the Son of God, who is the Judge of all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:349
verses.text: And in saying that there was a widow in the city, he refers to Jerusalem itself, which is a widow indeed, forsaken of her perfect, heavenly spouse, God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:350
verses.text: She calls Him her adversary, and not her Saviour; for she does not understand that which was said by the prophet Jeremiah: "Because they obeyed not the truth, a spirit of error shall speak then to this people and to Jerusalem".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:351
verses.text: And Isaiah also to the like effect: "Forasmuch as the people refuseth to drink the water of Siloam that goeth softly, but chooseth to have Rasin and Romeliah's son as king over you: therefore, lo, the Lord bringeth up upon you the water of the river, strong and full, even the king of Assyria".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:352
verses.text: By the king he means metaphorically Antichrist, as also another prophet saith: "And this man shall be the peace from me, when the Assyrian shall come up into your land, and when he shall tread in your mountains".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:353
verses.text: And in like manner Moses, knowing beforehand that the people would reject and disown the true Saviour of the world, and take part with error, and choose an earthly king, and set the heavenly King at nought, says: "Is not this laid up in store with me, and sealed up among my treasures? In the day of vengeance I will recompense (them), and in the time when their foot shall slide".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:354
verses.text: They did slide, therefore, in all things, as they were found to be in harmony with the truth in nothing: neither as concerns the law, because they became transgressors; nor as concerns the prophets, because they cut off even the prophets themselves; nor as concerns the voice of the Gospels, because they crucified the Saviour Himself; nor in believing the apostles, because they persecuted them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:355
verses.text: At all times they showed themselves enemies and betrayers of the truth, and were found to be haters of God, and not lovers of Him; and such they shall be then when they find opportunity: for, rousing themselves against the servants of God, they will seek to obtain vengeance by the hand of a mortal man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:356
verses.text: And he, being puffed up with pride by their subserviency, will begin to despatch missives against the saints, commanding to cut them all off everywhere, on the ground of their refusal to reverence and worship him as God, according to the word of Esaias: "Woe to the wings of the vessels of the land, beyond the rivers of Ethiopia: (woe to him) who sendeth sureties by the sea, and letters of papyrus (upon the water; for nimble messengers will go) to a nation anxious and expectant, and a people strange and bitter against them; a nation hopeless and trodden down".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:357
verses.text: But we who hope for the Son of God are persecuted and trodden down by those unbelievers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:358
verses.text: For the wings of the vessels are the churches; and the sea is the world, in which the Church is set, like a ship tossed in the deep, but not destroyed; for she has with her the skilled Pilot, Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:359
verses.text: And she bears in her midst also the trophy (which is erected) over death; for she carries with her the cross of the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:360
verses.text: For her prow is the east, and her stern is the west, and her hold is the south, and her tillers are the two Testaments; and the ropes that stretch around her are the love of Christ, which binds the Church; and the net which she bears with her is the laver of the regeneration which renews the believing, whence too are these glories.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:361
verses.text: As the wind the Spirit from heaven is present, by whom those who believe are sealed: she has also anchors of iron accompanying her, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:362
verses.text: , the holy commandments of Christ Himself, which are strong as iron.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:363
verses.text: She has also mariners on the right and on the left, assessors like the holy angels, by whom the Church is always governed and defended.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:364
verses.text: The ladder in her leading up to the sailyard is an emblem of the passion of Christ, which brings the faithful to the ascent of heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:365
verses.text: And the top-sails aloft upon the yard are the company of prophets, martyrs, and apostles, who have entered into their rest in the kingdom of Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:366
verses.text: Now, concerning the tribulation of the persecution which is to fall upon the Church from the adversary, John also speaks thus: "And I saw a great and wondrous sign in heaven; a woman clothed with the sun, and the moon under her feet, and upon her head a crown of twelve stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:367
verses.text: And she, being with child, cries, travailing in birth, and pained to be delivered.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:368
verses.text: And the dragon stood before the woman which was ready to be delivered, for to devour her child as soon as it was born.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:369
verses.text: And she brought forth a man-child, who is to rule all the nations: and the child was caught up unto God and to His throne.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:370
verses.text: And the woman fled into the wilderness, where she hath the place prepared of God, that they should feed her there a thousand two hundred and threescore days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:371
verses.text: And then when the dragon saw it, he persecuted the woman which brought forth the man-child.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:372
verses.text: And to the woman were given two wings of the great eagle, that she might fly into the wilderness, where she is nourished for a time, and times, and half a time, from the face of the serpent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:373
verses.text: And the serpent cast (out of his mouth water as a flood after the woman, that he might cause her to be carried away of the flood.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:374
verses.text: And the earth helped the woman, and opened her mouth, and swallowed up the flood which the dragon cast) out of his mouth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:375
verses.text: And the dragon was wroth with the woman, and went to make war with the saints of her seed, which keep the commandments of God, and have the testimony of Jesus".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:376
verses.text: By the woman then clothed with the sun," he meant most manifestly the Church, endued with the Father's word, whose brightness is above the sun.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:377
verses.text: And by the "moon under her feet" he referred to her being adorned, like the moon, with heavenly glory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:378
verses.text: And the words, "upon her head a crown of twelve stars," refer to the twelve apostles by whom the Church was founded.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:379
verses.text: And those, "she, being with child, cries, travailing in birth, and pained to be delivered," mean that the Church will not cease to bear from her heart the Word that is persecuted by the unbelieving in the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:380
verses.text: "And she brought forth," he says, "a man-child, who is to rule all the nations;" by which is meant that the Church, always bringing forth Christ, the perfect man-child of God, who is declared to be God and man, becomes the instructor of all the nations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:381
verses.text: And the words, "her child was caught up unto God and to His throne," signify that he who is always born of her is a heavenly king, and not an earthly; even as David also declared of old when he said, "The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit Thou at my right hand, until I make Thine enemies Thy footstool".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:382
verses.text: "And the dragon," he says, "saw and persecuted the woman which brought forth the man-child.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:383
verses.text: And to the woman were given two wings of the great eagle, that she might fly into the wilderness, where she is nourished for a time, and times, and half a time, from the face of the serpent".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:384
verses.text: That refers to the one thousand two hundred and threescore days (the half of the week) during which the tyrant is to reign and persecute the Church, which flees from city to city, and seeks concealment in the wilderness among the mountains, possessed of no other defence than the two wings of the great eagle, that is to say, the faith of Jesus Christ, who, in stretching forth His holy hands on the holy tree, unfolded two wings, the right and the left, and called to Him all who believed upon Him, and covered them as a hen her chickens.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:385
verses.text: For by the mouth of Malachi also He speaks thus:  "And unto you that fear my name shall the Sun of righteousness arise with healing in His wings".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:386
verses.text: The Lord also says, "When ye shall see the abomination of desolation stand in the holy place (whoso readeth, let him understand), then let them which be in Judea flee into the mountains, and let him which is on the housetop not come down to take his clothes; neither let him which is in the field return back to take anything out of his house.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:387
verses.text: And woe unto them that are with child, and to them that give suck, in those days! for then shall be great tribulation, such as was not since the beginning of the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:388
verses.text: And except those days should be shortened, there should no flesh be saved".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:389
verses.text: And Daniel says, "And they shall place the abomination of desolation a thousand two hundred and ninety days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:390
verses.text: Blessed is he that waiteth, and cometh to the thousand two hundred and ninety-five days".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:391
verses.text: And the blessed Apostle Paul, writing to the Thessalonians, says: "Now we beseech you, brethren, concerning the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, and our gathering together at it, that ye be not soon shaken in mind, or be troubled, neither by spirit, nor by word, nor by letters as from us, as that the day of the Lord is at hand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:392
verses.text: Let no man deceive you by any means; for (that day shall not come) except there come the falling away first, and that man of sin be revealed, the son of perdition, who opposeth and exalteth himself above all that is called God, or that is worshipped: so that he sitteth in the temple of God, showing himself that he is God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:393
verses.text: Remember ye not, that when I was yet with you, I told you these things? And now ye know what withholdeth, that he might be revealed in his time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:394
verses.text: For the mystery of iniquity doth already work; only he who now letteth (will let), until he be taken out of the way.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:395
verses.text: And then shall that wicked be revealed, whom the Lord Jesus shall consume with the Spirit of His mouth, and shall destroy with the brightness of His coming: (even him) whose coming is after the working of Satan, with all power, and signs, and lying wonders, and with all deceivableness of unrighteousness in them that perish; because they received not the love of the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:396
verses.text: And for this cause God shall send them strong delusion, that they should believe a lie:  that they all might be damned who believed not the truth, but had pleasure in unrighteousness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:397
verses.text: And Esaias says, "Let the wicked be cut off, that he behold not the glory of the Lord".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:398
verses.text: These things, then, being to come to pass, beloved, and the one week being divided into two parts, and the abomination of desolation being manifested then, and the two prophets and forerunners of the Lord having finished their course, and the whole world finally approaching the consummation, what remains but the coming of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ from heaven, for whom we have looked in hope? who shall bring the conflagration and just judgment upon all who have refused to believe on Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:399
verses.text: For the Lord says, "And when these things begin to come to pass, then look up, and lift up your heads; for your redemption draweth nigh".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:400
verses.text: "And there shall not a hair of your head perish".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:401
verses.text: "For as the lightning cometh out of the east, and shineth even unto the west, so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:402
verses.text: For wheresoever the carcase is, there will the eagles be gathered together".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:403
verses.text: Now the fall took place in paradise; for Adam fell there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:404
verses.text: And He says again, "Then shall the Son of man send His angels, and they shall gather together His elect from the four winds of heaven".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:405
verses.text: And David also, in announcing prophetically the judgment and coming of the Lord, says, "His going forth is from the end of the heaven, and His circuit unto the end of the heaven: and there is no one hid from the heat thereof".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:406
verses.text: By the heat he means the conflagration.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:407
verses.text: And Esaias speaks thus:  "Come, my people, enter thou into thy chamber, (and) shut thy door: hide thyself as it were for a little moment, until the indignation of the Lord be overpast".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:408
verses.text: And Paul in like manner:  "For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who hold the truth of God in unrighteousness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:409
verses.text: Moreover, concerning the resurrection and the kingdom of the saints, Daniel says, "And many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth shall arise, some to everlasting life, (and some to shame and everlasting contempt)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:410
verses.text: Esaias says, "The dead men shall arise, and they that are in their tombs shall awake; for the dew from thee is healing to them".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:411
verses.text: The Lord says, "Many in that day shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and they that hear shall live".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:412
verses.text: And the prophet says, "Awake, thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:413
verses.text: And John says, "Blessed and holy is he that hath part in the first resurrection: on such the second death hath no power".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:414
verses.text: For the second death is the lake of fire that burneth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:415
verses.text: And again the Lord says, "Then shall the righteous shine forth as the sun shineth in his glory".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:416
verses.text: And to the saints He will say, "Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:417
verses.text: But what saith He to the wicked? "Depart from me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels, which my Father hath prepared".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:418
verses.text: And John says, "Without are dogs, and sorcerers, and whoremongers, and murderers, and idolaters, and whosoever maketh and loveth a lie; for your part is in the hell of fire".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:419
verses.text: And in like manner also Esaias:  "And they shall go forth and look upon the carcases of the men that have transgressed against me.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:420
verses.text: And their worm shall not die, neither shall their fire be quenched; and they shall be for a spectacle to all flesh".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:421
verses.text: Concerning the resurrection of the righteous, Paul also speaks thus in writing to the Thessalonians:  "We would not have you to be ignorant concerning them which are asleep, that ye sorrow not even as others which have no hope.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:422
verses.text: For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so them also which sleep in Jesus will God bring with Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:423
verses.text: For this we say unto you by the word of the Lord, that we which are alive (and) remain unto the coming of the Lord, shall not prevent them which are asleep.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:424
verses.text: For the Lord Himself shall descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice and trump of God, and the dead in Christ shall rise first.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:425
verses.text: Then we which are alive (and) remain shall be caught up together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord in the air; and so shall we ever be with the Lord".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:426
verses.text: These things, then, I have set shortly before thee, O Theophilus, drawing them from Scripture itself, in order that, maintaining in faith what is written, and anticipating the things that are to be, thou mayest keep thyself void of offence both toward God and toward men, "looking for that blessed hope and appearing of our God and Saviour," when, having raised the saints among us, He will rejoice with them, glorifying the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 1:427
verses.text: To Him be the glory unto the endless ages of the ages, Amen.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:1
verses.text: Expository Treatise Against the Jews.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:2
verses.text: Now, then, incline thine ear to me, and hear my words, and give heed, thou Jew.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:3
verses.text: Many a time dost thou boast thyself, in that thou didst condemn Jesus of Nazareth to death, and didst give Him vinegar and gall to drink; and thou dost vaunt thyself because of this.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:4
verses.text: Come therefore, and let us consider together whether perchance thou dost not boast unrighteously, O Israel, (and) whether that small portion of vinegar and gall has not brought down this fearful threatening upon thee, (and) whether this is not the cause of thy present condition involved in these myriad troubles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:5
verses.text: Let him then be introduced before us who speaketh by the Holy Spirit, and saith truth—David the son of Jesse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:6
verses.text: He, singing a certain strain with prophetic reference to the true Christ, celebrated our God by the Holy Spirit, (and) declared clearly all that befell Him by the hands of the Jews in His passion; in which (strain) the Christ who humbled Himself and took unto Himself the form of the servant Adam, calls upon God the Father in heaven as it were in our person, and speaks thus in the sixty-ninth Psalm:  "Save me, O God; for the waters are come in unto my soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:7
verses.text: I am sunk in the mire of the abyss," that is to say, in the corruption of Hades, on account of the transgression in paradise; and "there is no substance," that is, help.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:8
verses.text: "My eyes failed while I hoped (or, from my hoping) upon my God; when will He come and save me?".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:9
verses.text: Then, in what next follows, Christ speaks, as it were, in His own person: "Then I restored that," says He, "which I took not away;" that is, on account of the sin of Adam I endured the death which was not mine by sinning.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:10
verses.text: "For, O God, Thou knowest my foolishness; and my sins are not hid from Thee," that is, "for I did not sin," as He means it; and for this reason (it is added), "Let not them be ashamed who want to see" my resurrection on the third day, to wit, the apostles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:11
verses.text: "Because for Thy sake," that is, for the sake of obeying Thee, "I have borne reproach," namely the cross, when "they covered my face with shame," that is to say, the Jews; when "I became a stranger unto my brethren after the flesh, and an alien unto my mother's children," meaning (by the mother) the synagogue.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:12
verses.text: "For the zeal of Thine house, Father, hath eaten me up; and the reproaches of them that reproached Thee are fallen on me," and of them that sacrificed to idols.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:13
verses.text: Wherefore "they that sit in the gate spoke against me," for they crucified me without the gate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:14
verses.text: "And they that drink sang against me," that is, (they who drink wine) at the feast of the passover.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:15
verses.text: "But as for me, in my prayer unto Thee, O Lord, I said, Father, forgive them," namely the Gentiles, because it is the time for favour with Gentiles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:16
verses.text: "Let not then the hurricane (of temptations) overwhelm me, neither let the deep (that is, Hades) swallow me up: for Thou wilt not leave my soul in hell (Hades); neither let the pit shut her mouth upon me," that is, the sepulchre.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:17
verses.text: "By reason of mine enemies, deliver me," that the Jews may not boast, saying, Let us consume him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:18
verses.text: Now Christ prayed all this economically as man; being, however, true God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:19
verses.text: But, as I have already said, it was the "form of the servant" that spake and suffered these things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:20
verses.text: Wherefore He added, "My soul looked for reproach and trouble," that is, I suffered of my own will, (and) not by any compulsion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:21
verses.text: Yet "I waited for one to mourn with me, and there was none," for all my disciples forsook me and fled; and for a "comforter, and I found none".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:22
verses.text: Listen with understanding, O Jew, to what the Christ says: "They gave me gall for my meat; and in my thirst they gave me vinegar to drink".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:23
verses.text: And these things He did indeed endure from you.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:24
verses.text: Hear the Holy Ghost tell you also what return He made to you for that little portion of vinegar.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:25
verses.text: For the prophet says, as in the person of God, "Let their table become a snare and retribution".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:26
verses.text: Of what retribution does He speak? Manifestly, of the misery which has now got hold of thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:27
verses.text: And then hear what follows:  "Let their eyes be darkened, that they see not".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:28
verses.text: And surely ye have been darkened in the eyes of your soul with a darkness utter and everlasting.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:29
verses.text: For now that the true light has arisen, ye wander as in the night, and stumble on places with no roads, and fall headlong, as having forsaken the way that saith, "I am the way".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:30
verses.text: Furthermore, hear this yet more serious word: "And their back do thou bend always;" that means, in order that they may be slaves to the nations, not four hundred and thirty years as in Egypt, nor seventy as in Babylon, but bend them to servitude, he says, "always".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:31
verses.text: In fine, then, how dost thou indulge vain hopes, expecting to be delivered from the misery which holdeth thee? For that is somewhat strange.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:32
verses.text: And not unjustly has he imprecated this blindness of eyes upon thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:33
verses.text: But because thou didst cover the eyes of Christ, (and) thus thou didst beat Him, for this reason, too, bend thou thy back for servitude always.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:34
verses.text: And whereas thou didst pour out His blood in indignation, hear what thy recompense shall be: "Pour out Thine indignation upon them, and let Thy wrathful anger take hold of them;" and, "Let their habitation be desolate," to wit, their celebrated temple.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:35
verses.text: But why, O prophet, tell us, and for what reason, was the temple made desolate? Was it on account of that ancient fabrication of the calf? Was it on account of the idolatry of the people? Was it for the blood of the prophets? Was it for the adultery and fornication of Israel? By no means, he says; for in all these transgressions they always found pardon open to them, and benignity; but it was because they killed the Son of their Benefactor, for He is coeternal with the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:36
verses.text: Whence He saith, "Father, let their temple be made desolate; for they have persecuted Him whom Thou didst of Thine own will smite for the salvation of the world;" that is, they have persecuted me with a violent and unjust death, "and they have added to the pain of my wounds".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:37
verses.text: In former time, as the Lover of man, I had pain on account of the straying of the Gentiles; but to this pain they have added another, by going also themselves astray.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:38
verses.text: Wherefore "add iniquity to their iniquity, and tribulation to tribulation, and let them not enter into Thy righteousness," that is, into Thy kingdom; but "let them be blotted out of the book of the living, and not be written with the righteous," that is, with their holy fathers and patriarchs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:39
verses.text: What sayest thou to this, O Jew? It is neither Matthew nor Paul that saith these things, but David, thine anointed, who awards and declares these terrible sentences on account of Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:40
verses.text: And like the great Job, addressing you who speak against the righteous and true, he says, "Thou didst barter the Christ like a slave, thou didst go to Him like a robber in the garden".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:41
verses.text: I produce now the prophecy of Solomon, which speaketh of Christ, and announces clearly and perspicuously things concerning the Jews; and those which not only are befalling them at the present time, but those, too, which shall befall them in the future age, on account of the contumacy and audacity which they exhibited toward the Prince of Life; for the prophet says, "The ungodly said, reasoning with themselves, but not aright," that is, about Christ, "Let us lie in wait for the righteous, because he is not for our turn, and he is clean contrary to our doings and words, and upbraideth us with our offending the law, and professeth to have knowledge of God; and he calleth himself the Child of God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:42
verses.text: And then he says, "He is grievous to us even to behold; for his life is not like other men's, and his ways are of another fashion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:43
verses.text: We are esteemed of him as counterfeits, and he abstaineth from our ways as from filthiness, and pronounceth the end of the just to be blessed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:44
verses.text: And again, listen to this, O Jew! None of the righteous or prophets called himself the Son of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:45
verses.text: And therefore, as in the person of the Jews, Solomon speaks again of this righteous one, who is Christ, thus: "He was made to reprove our thoughts, and he maketh his boast that God is his Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:46
verses.text: Let us see, then, if his words be true, and let us prove what shall happen in the end of him; for if the just man be the Son of God, He will help him, and deliver him from the hand of his enemies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:47
verses.text: Let us condemn him with a shameful death, for by his own saying he shall be respected".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:48
verses.text: And again David, in the Psalms, says with respect to the future age, "Then shall He" (namely Christ) "speak unto them in His wrath, and vex them in His sore displeasure".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:49
verses.text: And again Solomon says concerning Christ and the Jews, that "when the righteous shall stand in great boldness before the face of such as have afflicted Him, and made no account of His words, when they see it they shall be troubled with terrible fear, and shall be amazed at the strangeness of His salvation; and they, repenting and groaning for anguish of spirit, shall say within themselves, This is He whom we had sometimes in derision and a proverb of reproach; we fools accounted His life madness, and His end to be without honour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:50
verses.text: How is He numbered among the children of God, and His lot is among the saints? Therefore have we erred from the way of truth, and the light of righteousness hath not shined unto us, and the sun of righteousness rose not on us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:51
verses.text: We wearied ourselves in the way of wickedness and destruction; we have gone through deserts where there lay no way: but as for the way of the Lord, we have not known it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:52
verses.text: What hath our pride profited us? all those things are passed away like a shadow".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 2:53
verses.text: The conclusion is wanting.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:1
verses.text: Against Plato, on the Cause of the Universe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:2
verses.text: And this is the passage regarding demons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:3
verses.text: But now we must speak of Hades, in which the souls both of the righteous and the unrighteous are detained.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:4
verses.text: Hades is a place in the created system, rude, a locality beneath the earth, in which the light of the world does not shine; and as the sun does not shine in this locality, there must necessarily be perpetual darkness there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:5
verses.text: This locality has been destined to be as it were a guard-house for souls, at which the angels are stationed as guards, distributing according to each one's deeds the temporary punishments for (different) characters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:6
verses.text: And in this locality there is a certain place set apart by itself, a lake of unquenchable fire, into which we suppose no one has ever yet been cast; for it is prepared against the day determined by God, in which one sentence of righteous judgment shall be justly applied to all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:7
verses.text: And the unrighteous, and those who believed not God, who have honoured as God the vain works of the hands of men, idols fashioned (by themselves), shall be sentenced to this endless punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:8
verses.text: But the righteous shall obtain the incorruptible and unfading kingdom, who indeed are at present detained in Hades, but not in the same place with the unrighteous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:9
verses.text: For to this locality there is one descent, at the gate whereof we believe an archangel is stationed with a host.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:10
verses.text: And when those who are conducted by the angels appointed unto the souls have passed through this gate, they do not proceed on one and the same way; but the righteous, being conducted in the light toward the right, and being hymned by the angels stationed at the place, are brought to a locality full of light.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:11
verses.text: And there the righteous from the beginning dwell, not ruled by necessity, but enjoying always the contemplation of the blessings which are in their view, and delighting themselves with the expectation of others ever new, and deeming those ever better than these.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:12
verses.text: And that place brings no toils to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:13
verses.text: There, there is neither fierce heat, nor cold, nor thorn; but the face of the fathers and the righteous is seen to be always smiling, as they wait for the rest and eternal revival in heaven which succeed this location.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:14
verses.text: And we call it by the name Abraham's bosom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:15
verses.text: But the unrighteous are dragged toward the left by angels who are ministers of punishment, and they go of their own accord no longer, but are dragged by force as prisoners.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:16
verses.text: And the angels appointed over them send them along, reproaching them and threatening them with an eye of terror, forcing them down into the lower parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:17
verses.text: And when they are brought there, those appointed to that service drag them on to the confines or hell.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:18
verses.text: And those who are so near hear incessantly the agitation, and feel the hot smoke.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:19
verses.text: And when that vision is so near, as they see the terrible and excessively glowing spectacle of the fire, they shudder in horror at the expectation of the future judgment, (as if they were) already feeling the power of their punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:20
verses.text: And again, where they see the place of the fathers and the righteous, they are also punished there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:21
verses.text: For a deep and vast abyss is set there in the midst, so that neither can any of the righteous in sympathy think to pass it, nor any of the unrighteous dare to cross it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:22
verses.text: Thus far, then, on the subject of Hades, in which the souls of all are detained until the time which God has determined; and then He will accomplish a resurrection of all, not by transferring souls into other bodies, but by raising the bodies themselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:23
verses.text: And if, O Greeks, ye refuse credit to this because ye see these (bodies) in their dissolution, learn not to be incredulous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:24
verses.text: For if ye believe that the soul is originated and is made immortal by God, according to the opinion of Plato, in time, ye ought not to refuse to believe that God is able also to raise the body, which is composed of the same elements, and make it immortal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:25
verses.text: To be able in one thing, and to be unable in another, is a word which cannot be said of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:26
verses.text: We therefore believe that the body also is raised.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:27
verses.text: For if it become corrupt, it is not at least destroyed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:28
verses.text: For the earth receiving its remains preserves them, and they, becoming as it were seed, and being wrapped up with the richer part of earth, spring up and bloom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:29
verses.text: And that which is sown is sown indeed bare grain; but at the command of God the Artificer it buds, and is raised arrayed and glorious, but not until it has first died, and been dissolved, and mingled with earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:30
verses.text: Not, therefore, without good reason do we believe in the resurrection of the body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:31
verses.text: Moreover, if it is dissolved in its season on account of the primeval transgression, and is committed to the earth as to a furnace, to be moulded again anew, it is not raised the same thing as it is now, but pure and no longer corruptible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:32
verses.text: And to every body its own proper soul will be given again; and the soul, being endued again with it, shall not be grieved, but shall rejoice together with it, abiding itself pure with it also pure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:33
verses.text: And as it now sojourns with it in the world righteously, and finds it in nothing now a traitor, it will receive it again (the body) with great joy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:34
verses.text: But the unrighteous will receive their bodies unchanged, and unransomed from suffering and disease, and unglorified, and still with all the ills in which they died.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:35
verses.text: And whatever manner of persons they (were when they) lived without faith, as such they shall be faithfully judged.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:36
verses.text: For all, the righteous and the unrighteous alike, shall be brought before God the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:37
verses.text: For the Father hath committed all judgment to Him; and in fulfilment of the Father's counsel, He cometh as Judge whom we call Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:38
verses.text: For it is not Minos and Rhadamanthys that are to judge (the world), as ye fancy, O Greeks, but He whom God the Father hath glorified, of whom we have spoken elsewhere more in particular, for the profit of those who seek the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:39
verses.text: He, in administering the righteous judgment of the Father to all, assigns to each what is righteous according to his works.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:40
verses.text: And being present at His judicial decision, all, both men and angels and demons, shall utter one voice, saying, "Righteous is Thy judgment".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:41
verses.text: Of which voice the justification will be seen in the awarding to each that which is just; since to those who have done well shall be assigned righteously eternal bliss, and to the lovers of iniquity shall be given eternal punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:42
verses.text: And the fire which is unquenchable and without end awaits these latter, and a certain fiery worm which dieth not, and which does not waste the body, but continues bursting forth from the body with unending pain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:43
verses.text: No sleep will give them rest; no night will soothe them; no death will deliver them from punishment; no voice of interceding friends will profit them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:44
verses.text: For neither are the righteous seen by them any longer, nor are they worthy of remembrance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:45
verses.text: But the righteous will remember only the righteous deeds by which they reached the heavenly kingdom, in which there is neither sleep, nor pain, nor corruption, nor care, nor night, nor day measured by time; nor sun traversing in necessary course the circle of heaven, which marks the limits of seasons, or the points measured out for the life of man so easily read; nor moon waning or waxing, or inducing the changes of seasons, or moistening the earth; no burning sun, no changeful Bear, no Orion coming forth, no numerous wandering of stars, no painfully-trodden earth, no abode of paradise hard to find; no furious roaring of the sea, forbidding one to touch or traverse it; but this too will be readily passable for the righteous, although it lacks no water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:46
verses.text: There will be no heaven inaccessible to men, nor will the way of its ascent be one impossible to find; and there will be no earth unwrought, or toilsome for men, but one producing fruit spontaneously in beauty and order; nor will there be generation of wild beasts again, nor the bursting substance of other creatures.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:47
verses.text: Neither with man will there be generation again, but the number of the righteous remains indefectible with the righteous angels and spirits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:48
verses.text: Ye who believe these words, O men, will be partakers with the righteous, and will have part in these future blessings, which "eye hath not seen nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 3:49
verses.text: To Him be the glory and the power, for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:1
verses.text: Against the Heresy of One Noetus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:2
verses.text: Some others are secretly introducing another doctrine, who have become disciples of one Noetus, who was a native of Smyrna, (and) lived not very long ago.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:3
verses.text: This person was greatly puffed up and inflated with pride, being inspired by the conceit of a strange spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:4
verses.text: He alleged that Christ was the Father Himself, and that the Father Himself was born, and suffered, and died.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:5
verses.text: Ye see what pride of heart and what a strange inflated spirit had insinuated themselves into him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:6
verses.text: From his other actions, then, the proof is already given us that he spoke not with a pure spirit; for he who blasphemes against the Holy Ghost is cast out from the holy inheritance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:7
verses.text: He alleged that he was himself Moses, and that Aaron was his brother.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:8
verses.text: When the blessed presbyters heard this, they summoned him before the Church, and examined him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:9
verses.text: But he denied at first that he held such opinions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:10
verses.text: Afterwards, however, taking shelter among some, and having gathered round him some others who had embraced the same error, he wished thereafter to uphold his dogma openly as correct.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:11
verses.text: And the blessed presbyters called him again before them, and examined him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:12
verses.text: But he stood out against them, saying, "What evil, then, am I doing in glorifying Christ?"  And the presbyters replied to him, "We too know in truth one God; we know Christ; we know that the Son suffered even as He suffered, and died even as He died, and rose again on the third day, and is at the right hand of the Father, and cometh to judge the living and the dead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:13
verses.text: And these things which we have learned we allege".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:14
verses.text: Then, after examining him, they expelled him from the Church.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:15
verses.text: And he was carried to such a pitch of pride, that he established a school.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:16
verses.text: Now they seek to exhibit the foundation for their dogma by citing the word in the law, "I am the God of your fathers: ye shall have no other gods beside me;" and again in another passage, "I am the first," He saith, "and the last; and beside me there is none other".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:17
verses.text: Thus they say they prove that God is one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:18
verses.text: And then they answer in this manner: "If therefore I acknowledge Christ to be God, He is the Father Himself, if He is indeed God; and Christ suffered, being Himself God; and consequently the Father suffered, for He was the Father Himself".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:19
verses.text: But the case stands not thus; for the Scriptures do not set forth the matter in this manner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:20
verses.text: But they make use also of other testimonies, and say, Thus it is written:  "This is our God, and there shall none other be accounted of in comparison of Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:21
verses.text: He hath found out all the way of knowledge, and hath given it unto Jacob His servant (son), and to Israel His beloved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:22
verses.text: Afterward did He show Himself upon earth, and conversed with men".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:23
verses.text: You see, then, he says, that this is God, who is the only One, and who afterwards did show Himself, and conversed with men".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:24
verses.text: And in another place he says, "Egypt hath laboured; and the merchandise of Ethiopia and the Sabeans, men of stature, shall come over unto thee, (and they shall be slaves to thee); and they shall come after thee bound with manacles, and they shall fall down unto thee, because God is in thee; and they shall make supplication unto thee: and there is no God beside thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:25
verses.text: For Thou art God, and we knew not; God of Israel, the Saviour".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:26
verses.text: Do you see, he says, how the Scriptures proclaim one God? And as this is clearly exhibited, and these passages are testimonies to it, I am under necessity, he says, since one is acknowledged, to make this One the subject of suffering.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:27
verses.text: For Christ was God, and suffered on account of us, being Himself the Father, that He might be able also to save us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:28
verses.text: And we cannot express ourselves otherwise, he says; for the apostle also acknowledges one God, when he says, "Whose are the fathers, (and) of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:29
verses.text: In this way, then, they choose to set forth these things, and they make use only of one class of passages; just in the same one-sided manner that Theodotus employed when he sought to prove that Christ was a mere man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:30
verses.text: But neither has the one party nor the other understood the matter rightly, as the Scriptures themselves confute their senselessness, and attest the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:31
verses.text: See, brethren, what a rash and audacious dogma they have introduced, when they say without shame, the Father is Himself Christ, Himself the Son, Himself was born, Himself suffered, Himself raised Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:32
verses.text: But it is not so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:33
verses.text: The Scriptures speak what is right; but Noetus is of a different mind from them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:34
verses.text: Yet, though Noetus does not understand the truth, the Scriptures are not at once to be repudiated.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:35
verses.text: For who will not say that there is one God? Yet he will not on that account deny the economy (i-e:, the number and disposition of persons in the Trinity).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:36
verses.text: The proper way, therefore, to deal with the question is first of all to refute the interpretation put upon these passages by these men, and then to explain their real meaning.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:37
verses.text: For it is right, in the first place, to expound the truth that the Father is one God, "of whom is every family," "by whom are all things, of whom are all things, and we in Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:38
verses.text: Let us, as I said, see how he is confuted, and then let us set forth the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:39
verses.text: Now he quotes the words, "Egypt has laboured, and the merchandise of Ethiopia and the Sabeans," and so forth on to the words, "For Thou art the God of Israel, the Saviour".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:40
verses.text: And these words he cites without understanding what precedes them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:41
verses.text: For whenever they wish to attempt anything underhand, they mutilate the Scriptures.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:42
verses.text: But let him quote the passage as a whole, and he will discover the reason kept in view in writing it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:43
verses.text: For we have the beginning of the section a little above; and we ought, of course, to commence there in showing to whom and about whom the passage speaks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:44
verses.text: For above, the beginning of the section stands thus: "Ask me concerning my sons and my daughters, and concerning the work of my hands command ye me.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:45
verses.text: I have made the earth, and man upon it: I with my hand have stablished the heaven; I have commanded all the stars.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:46
verses.text: I have raised him up, and all his ways are straight.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:47
verses.text: He shall build my city, and he shall turn back the captivity; not for price nor reward, said the Lord of hosts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:48
verses.text: Thus said the Lord of hosts, Egypt hath laboured, and the merchandise of Ethiopia and the Sabeans, men of stature, shall come over unto thee, and they shall be slaves to thee: and they shall come after thee bound with manacles, and they shall fall down unto thee; and they shall make supplication unto thee, because God is in thee; and there is no God beside thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:49
verses.text: For Thou art God, and we knew not; the God of Israel, the Saviour".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:50
verses.text: "In thee, therefore," says he, "God is".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:51
verses.text: But in whom is God except in Christ Jesus, the Father's Word, and the mystery of the economy? And again, exhibiting the truth regarding Him, he points to the fact of His being in the flesh when He says, "I have raised Him up in righteousness, and all His ways are straight".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:52
verses.text: For what is this? Of whom does the Father thus testify? It is of the Son that the Father says, "I have raised Him up in righteousness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:53
verses.text: And that the Father did raise up His Son in righteousness, the Apostle Paul bears witness, saying, "But if the Spirit of Him that raised up Christ Jesus from the dead dwell in you, He that raised up Christ Jesus from the dead shall also quicken your mortal bodies by His Spirit that dwelleth in you".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:54
verses.text: Behold, the word spoken by the prophet is thus made good, "I have raised Him up in righteousness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:55
verses.text: And in saying, "God is in thee," he referred to the mystery of the economy, because when the Word was made incarnate and became man, the Father was in the Son, and the Son in the Father, while the Son was living among men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:56
verses.text: This, therefore, was signified, brethren, that in reality the mystery of the economy by the Holy Ghost and the Virgin was this Word, constituting yet one Son to God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:57
verses.text: And it is not simply that I say this, but He Himself attests it who came down from heaven; for He speaketh thus: "No man hath ascended up to heaven, but He that came down from heaven, even the Son of man which is in heaven".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:58
verses.text: What then can he seek beside what is thus written? Will he say, forsooth, that flesh was in heaven? Yet there is the flesh which was presented by the Father's Word as an offering,—the flesh that came by the Spirit and the Virgin, (and was) demonstrated to be the perfect Son of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:59
verses.text: It is evident, therefore, that He offered Himself to the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:60
verses.text: And before this there was no flesh in heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:61
verses.text: Who, then, was in heaven but the Word unincarnate, who was despatched to show that He was upon earth and was also in heaven?  For He was Word, He was Spirit, He was Power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:62
verses.text: The same took to Himself the name common and current among men, and was called from the beginning the Son of man on account of what He was to be, although He was not yet man, as Daniel testifies when he says, "I saw, and behold one like the Son of man came on the clouds of heaven".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:63
verses.text: Rightly, then, did he say that He who was in heaven was called from the beginning by this name, the Word of God, as being that from the beginning.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:64
verses.text: But what is meant, says he, in the other passage: "This is God, and there shall none other be accounted of in comparison of Him?" That said he rightly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:65
verses.text: For in comparison of the Father who shall be accounted of? But he says: "This is our God; there shall none other be accounted of in comparison of Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:66
verses.text: He hath found out all the way of knowledge, and hath given it unto Jacob His servant, and to Israel His beloved".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:67
verses.text: He saith well.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:68
verses.text: For who is Jacob His servant, Israel His beloved, but He of whom He crieth, saying, "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased: hear ye Him?" Having received, then, all knowledge from the Father, the perfect Israel, the true Jacob, afterward did show Himself upon earth, and conversed with men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:69
verses.text: And who, again, is meant by Israel but a man who sees God? and there is no one who sees God except the Son alone, the perfect man who alone declares the will of the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:70
verses.text: For John also says, "No man hath seen God at any time; the only-begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the Father, He hath declared Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:71
verses.text: And again: "He who came down from heaven testifieth what He hath heard and seen".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:72
verses.text: This, then, is He to whom the Father hath given all knowledge, who did show Himself upon earth, and conversed with men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:73
verses.text: Let us look next at the apostle's word: "Whose are the fathers, of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over all, God blessed for ever".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:74
