verses.text: This word declares the mystery of the truth rightly and clearly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:75
verses.text: He who is over all is God; for thus He speaks boldly, "All things are delivered unto me of my Father".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:76
verses.text: He who is over all, God blessed, has been born; and having been made man, He is (yet) God for ever.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:77
verses.text: For to this effect John also has said, "Which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:78
verses.text: And well has he named Christ the Almighty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:79
verses.text: For in this he has said only what Christ testifies of Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:80
verses.text: For Christ gave this testimony, and said, "All things are delivered unto me of my Father;" and Christ rules all things, and has been appointed Almighty by the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:81
verses.text: And in like manner Paul also, in setting forth the truth that all things are delivered unto Him, said, "Christ the first-fruits; afterwards they that are Christ's at His coming.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:82
verses.text: Then cometh the end, when He shall have delivered up the kingdom to God, even the Father; when He shall have put down all rule, and all authority, and power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:83
verses.text: For He must reign, till He hath put all enemies under His feet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:84
verses.text: The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:85
verses.text: For all things are put under Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:86
verses.text: But when He saith, All things are put under Him, it is manifest that He is excepted which did put all things under Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:87
verses.text: Then shall He also Himself be subject to Him who put all things under Him, that God may be all in all".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:88
verses.text: If, therefore, all things are put under Him with the exception of Him who put them under Him, He is Lord of all, and the Father is Lord of Him, that in all there might be manifested one God, to whom all things are made subject together with Christ, to whom the Father hath made all things subject, with the exception of Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:89
verses.text: And this, indeed, is said by Christ Himself, as when in the Gospel He confessed Him to be His Father and His God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:90
verses.text: For He speaks thus: "I go to my Father and your Father, and to my God and your God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:91
verses.text: If then, Noetus ventures to say that He is the Father Himself, to what father will he say Christ goes away according to the word of the Gospel?  But if he will have us abandon the Gospel and give credence to his senselessness, he expends his labour in vain; for "we ought to obey God rather than men".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:92
verses.text: If, again, he allege His own word when He said, "I and the Father are one," let him attend to the fact, and understand that He did not say, "I and the Father am one, but are one".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:93
verses.text: For the word areis not said of one person, but it refers to two persons, and one power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:94
verses.text: He has Himself made this clear, when He spake to His Father concerning the disciples, "The glory which Thou gavest me I have given them; that they may be one, even as we are one: I in them, and Thou in me, that they may be made perfect in one; that the world may know that Thou hast sent me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:95
verses.text: What have the Noetians to say to these things? Are all one body in respect of substance, or is it that we become one in the power and disposition of unity of mind? In the same manner the Son, who was sent and was not known of those who are in the world, confessed that He was in the Father in power and disposition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:96
verses.text: For the Son is the one mind of the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:97
verses.text: We who have the Father's mind believe so (in Him); but they who have it not have denied the Son.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:98
verses.text: And if, again, they choose to allege the fact that Philip inquired about the Father, saying, "Show us the Father, and it sufficeth us," to whom the Lord made answer in these terms: "Have I been so long time with you, and yet hast thou not known me, Philip? He that hath seen me hath seen the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:99
verses.text: Believest thou not that I am in the Father, and the Father in me?" and if they choose to maintain that their dogma is ratified by this passage, as if He owned Himself to be the Father, let them know that it is decidedly against them, and that they are confuted by this very word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:100
verses.text: For though Christ had spoken of Himself, and showed Himself among all as the Son, they had not yet recognised Him to be such, neither had they been able to apprehend or contemplate His real power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:101
verses.text: And Philip, not having been able to receive this, as far as it was possible to see it, requested to behold the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:102
verses.text: To whom then the Lord said, "Philip, have I been so long time with you, and yet hast thou not known me? He that hath seen me hath seen the Father".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:103
verses.text: By which He means, If thou hast seen me, thou mayest know the Father through me.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:104
verses.text: For through the image, which is like (the original), the Father is made readily known.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:105
verses.text: But if thou hast not known the image, which is the Son, how dost thou seek to see the Father? And that this is the case is made clear by the rest of the chapter, which signifies that the Son who "has been set forth was sent from the Father, and goeth to the Father".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:106
verses.text: Many other passages, or rather all of them, attest the truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:107
verses.text: A man, therefore, even though he will it not, is compelled to acknowledge God the Father Almighty, and Christ Jesus the Son of God, who, being God, became man, to whom also the Father made all things subject, Himself excepted, and the Holy Spirit; and that these, therefore, are three.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:108
verses.text: But if he desires to learn how it is shown still that there is one God, let him know that His power is one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:109
verses.text: As far as regards the power, therefore, God is one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:110
verses.text: But as far as regards the economy there is a threefold manifestation, as shall be proved afterwards when we give account of the true doctrine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:111
verses.text: In these things, however, which are thus set forth by us, we are at one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:112
verses.text: For there is one God in whom we must believe, but unoriginated, impassible, immortal, doing all things as He wills, in the way He wills, and when He wills.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:113
verses.text: What, then, will this Noetus, who knows nothing of the truth, dare to say to these things? And now, as Noetus has been confuted, let us turn to the exhibition of the truth itself, that we may establish the truth, against which all these mighty heresies have arisen without being able to state anything to the purpose.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:114
verses.text: There is, brethren, one God, the knowledge of whom we gain from the Holy Scriptures, and from no other source.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:115
verses.text: For just as a man, if he wishes to be skilled in the wisdom of this world, will find himself unable to get at it in any other way than by mastering the dogmas of philosophers, so all of us who wish to practise piety will be unable to learn its practice from any other quarter than the oracles of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:116
verses.text: Whatever things, then, the Holy Scriptures declare, at these let us look; and whatsoever things they teach, these let us learn; and as the Father wills our belief to be, let us believe; and as He wills the Son to be glorified, let us glorify Him; and as He wills the Holy Spirit to be bestowed, let us receive Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:117
verses.text: Not according to our own will, nor according to our own mind, nor yet as using violently those things which are given by God, but even as He has chosen to teach them by the Holy Scriptures, so let us discern them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:118
verses.text: God, subsisting alone, and having nothing contemporaneous with Himself, determined to create the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:119
verses.text: And conceiving the world in mind, and willing and uttering the word, He made it; and straightway it appeared, formed as it had pleased Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:120
verses.text: For us, then, it is sufficient simply to know that there was nothing contemporaneous with God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:121
verses.text: Beside Him there was nothing; but He, while existing alone, yet existed in plurality.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:122
verses.text: For He was neither without reason, nor wisdom, nor power, nor counsel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:123
verses.text: And all things were in Him, and He was the All.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:124
verses.text: When He willed, and as He willed, He manifested His word in the times determined by Him, and by Him He made all things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:125
verses.text: When He wills, He does; and when He thinks, He executes; and when He speaks, He manifests; when He fashions, He contrives in wisdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:126
verses.text: For all things that are made He forms by reason and wisdom—creating them in reason, and arranging them in wisdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:127
verses.text: He made them, then, as He pleased, for He was God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:128
verses.text: And as the Author, and fellow-Counsellor, and Framer of the things that are in formation, He begat the Word; and as He bears this Word in Himself, and that, too, as (yet) invisible to the world which is created, He makes Him visible; (and) uttering the voice first, and begetting Him as Light of Light, He set Him forth to the world as its Lord, (and) His own mind; and whereas He was visible formerly to Himself alone, and invisible to the world which is made, He makes Him visible in order that the world might see Him in His manifestation, and be capable of being saved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:129
verses.text: And thus there appeared another beside Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:130
verses.text: But when I say another, I do not mean that there are two Gods, but that it is only as light of light, or as water from a fountain, or as a ray from the sun.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:131
verses.text: For there is but one power, which is from the All; and the Father is the All, from whom cometh this Power, the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:132
verses.text: And this is the mind which came forth into the world, and was manifested as the Son of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:133
verses.text: All things, then, are by Him, and He alone is of the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:134
verses.text: Who then adduces a multitude of gods brought in, time after time? For all are shut up, however unwillingly, to admit this fact, that the All runs up into one.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:135
verses.text: If, then, all things run up into one, even according to Valentinus, and Marcion, and Cerinthus, and all their fooleries, they are also reduced, however unwillingly, to this position, that they must acknowledge that the One is the cause of all things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:136
verses.text: Thus, then, these too, though they wish it not, fall in with the truth, and admit that one God made all things according to His good pleasure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:137
verses.text: And He gave the law and the prophets; and in giving them, He made them speak by the Holy Ghost, in order that, being gifted with the inspiration of the Father's power, they might declare the Father's counsel and will.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:138
verses.text: Acting then in these (prophets), the Word spoke of Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:139
verses.text: For already He became His own herald, and showed that the Word would be manifested among men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:140
verses.text: And for this reason He cried thus:  "I am made manifest to them that sought me not; I am found of them that asked not for me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:141
verses.text: And who is He that is made manifest but the Word of the Father?—whom the Father sent, and in whom He showed to men the power proceeding from Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:142
verses.text: Thus, then, was the Word made manifest, even as the blessed John says.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:143
verses.text: For he sums up the things that were said by the prophets, and shows that this is the Word, by whom all things were made.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:144
verses.text: For he speaks to this effect: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:145
verses.text: All things were made by Him, and without Him was not anything made".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:146
verses.text: And beneath He says, "The world was made by Him, and the world knew Him not; He came unto His own, and His own received Him not".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:147
verses.text: If, then, said he, the world was made by Him, according to the word of the prophet, "By the Word of the Lord were the heavens made," then this is the Word that was also made manifest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:148
verses.text: We accordingly see the Word incarnate, and we know the Father by Him, and we believe in the Son, (and) we worship the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:149
verses.text: Let us then look at the testimony of Scripture, with respect to the announcement of the future manifestation of the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:150
verses.text: Now Jeremiah says, "Who hath stood in the counsel of the Lord, and hath perceived His Word?" But the Word of God alone is visible, while the word of man is audible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:151
verses.text: When he speaks of seeing the Word, I must believe that this visible (Word) has been sent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:152
verses.text: And there was none other (sent) but the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:153
verses.text: And that He was sent Peter testifies, when he says to the centurion Cornelius: "God sent His Word unto the children of Israel by the preaching of Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:154
verses.text: This is the God who is Lord of all".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:155
verses.text: If, then, the Word is sent by Jesus Christ, the will of the Father is Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:156
verses.text: These things then, brethren, are declared by the Scriptures.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:157
verses.text: And the blessed John, in the testimony of his Gospel, gives us an account of this economy (disposition) and acknowledges this Word as God, when he says, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:158
verses.text: If, then, the Word was with God, and was also God, what follows? Would one say that he speaks of two Gods? I shall not indeed speak of two Gods, but of one; of two Persons however, and of a third economy (disposition), viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:159
verses.text: , the grace of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:160
verses.text: For the Father indeed is One, but there are two Persons, because there is also the Son; and then there is the third, the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:161
verses.text: The Father decrees, the Word executes, and the Son is manifested, through whom the Father is believed on.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:162
verses.text: The economy of harmony is led back to one God; for God is One.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:163
verses.text: It is the Father who commands, and the Son who obeys, and the Holy Spirit who gives understanding: the Father who is above all, and the Son who is through all, and the Holy Spirit who is in all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:164
verses.text: And we cannot otherwise think of one God, but by believing in truth in Father and Son and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:165
verses.text: For the Jews glorified (or gloried in) the Father, but gave Him not thanks, for they did not recognise the Son.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:166
verses.text: The disciples recognised the Son, but not in the Holy Ghost; wherefore they also denied Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:167
verses.text: The Father's Word, therefore, knowing the economy (disposition) and the will of the Father, to wit, that the Father seeks to be worshipped in none other way than this, gave this charge to the disciples after He rose from the dead: "Go ye and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:168
verses.text: And by this He showed, that whosoever omitted any one of these, failed in glorifying God perfectly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:169
verses.text: For it is through this Trinity that the Father is glorified.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:170
verses.text: For the Father willed, the Son did, the Spirit manifested.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:171
verses.text: The whole Scriptures, then, proclaim this truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:172
verses.text: But some one will say to me, You adduce a thing strange to me, when you call the Son the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:173
verses.text: For John indeed speaks of the Word, but it is by a figure of speech.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:174
verses.text: Nay, it is by no figure of speech.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:175
verses.text: For while thus presenting this Word that was from the beginning, and has now been sent forth, he said below in the Apocalypse, "And I saw heaven opened, and behold a white horse; and He that sat upon him (was) Faithful and True; and in righteousness He doth judge and make war.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:176
verses.text: And His eyes (were) as flame of fire, and on His head were many crowns; and He had a name written that no man knew but He Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:177
verses.text: And He (was) clothed in a vesture dipped in blood:  and His name is called the Word of God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:178
verses.text: See then, brethren, how the vesture sprinkled with blood denoted in symbol the flesh, through which the impassible Word of God came under suffering, as also the prophets testify to me.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:179
verses.text: For thus speaks the blessed Micah:  "The house of Jacob provoked the Spirit of the Lord to anger.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:180
verses.text: These are their pursuits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:181
verses.text: Are not His words good with them, and do they walk rightly? And they have risen up in enmity against His countenance of peace, and they have stripped off His glory".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:182
verses.text: That means His suffering in the flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:183
verses.text: And in like manner also the blessed Paul says, "For what the law could not do, in that it was weak, God, sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, condemned sin in the flesh, that the righteousness of the law might be shown in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:184
verses.text: What Son of His own, then, did God send through the flesh but the Word, whom He addressed as Son because He was to become such (or be begotten) in the future? And He takes the common name for tender affection among men in being called the Son.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:185
verses.text: For neither was the Word, prior to incarnation and when by Himself, yet perfect Son, although He was perfect Word, only-begotten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:186
verses.text: Nor could the flesh subsist by itself apart from the Word, because it has its subsistence in the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:187
verses.text: Thus, then, one perfect Son of God was manifested.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:188
verses.text: And these indeed are testimonies bearing on the incarnation of the Word; and there are also very many others.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:189
verses.text: But let us also look at the subject in hand,—namely, the question, brethren, that in reality the Father's power, which is the Word, came down from heaven, and not the Father Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:190
verses.text: For thus He speaks: "I came forth from the Father, and am come".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:191
verses.text: Now what subject is meant in this sentence, "I came forth from the Father," but just the Word? And what is it that is begotten of Him, but just the Spirit, that is to say, the Word? But you will say to me, How is He begotten? In your own case you can give no explanation of the way in which you were begotten, although you see every day the cause according to man; neither can you tell with accuracy the economy in His case.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:192
verses.text: For you have it not in your power to acquaint yourself with the practised and indescribable art (method) of the Maker, but only to see, and understand, and believe that man is God's work.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:193
verses.text: Moreover, you are asking an account of the generation of the Word, whom God the Father in His good pleasure begat as He willed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:194
verses.text: Is it not enough for you to learn that God made the world, but do you also venture to ask whence He made it? Is it not enough for you to learn that the Son of God has been manifested to you for salvation if you believe, but do you also inquire curiously how He was begotten after the Spirit? No more than two, in sooth, have been put in trust to give the account of His generation after the flesh; and are you then so bold as to seek the account (of His generation) after the Spirit, which the Father keeps with Himself, intending to reveal it then to the holy ones and those worthy of seeing His face? Rest satisfied with the word spoken by Christ, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:195
verses.text: , "That which is born of the Spirit is spirit," just as, speaking by the prophet of the generation of the Word, He shows the fact that He is begotten, but reserves the question of the manner and means, to reveal it only in the time determined by Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:196
verses.text: For He speaks thus: "From the womb, before the morning star, I have begotten Thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:197
verses.text: These testimonies are sufficient for the believing who study truth, and the unbelieving credit no testimony.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:198
verses.text: For the Holy Spirit, indeed, in the person of the apostles, has testified to this, saying, "And who has believed our report?" Therefore let us not prove ourselves unbelieving, lest the word spoken be fulfilled in us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:199
verses.text: Let us believe then, dear brethren, according to the tradition of the apostles, that God the Word came down from heaven, (and entered) into the holy Virgin Mary, in order that, taking the flesh from her, and assuming also a human, by which I mean a rational soul, and becoming thus all that man is with the exception of sin, He might save fallen man, and confer immortality on men who believe on His name.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:200
verses.text: In all, therefore, the word of truth is demonstrated to us, to wit, that the Father is One, whose word is present (with Him), by whom He made all things; whom also, as we have said above, the Father sent forth in later times for the salvation of men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:201
verses.text: This (Word) was preached by the law and the prophets as destined to come into the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:202
verses.text: And even as He was preached then, in the same manner also did He come and manifest Himself, being by the Virgin and the Holy Spirit made a new man; for in that He had the heavenly (nature) of the Father, as the Word and the earthly (nature), as taking to Himself the flesh from the old Adam by the medium of the Virgin, He now, coming forth into the world, was manifested as God in a body, coming forth too as a perfect man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:203
verses.text: For it was not in mere appearance or by conversion, but in truth, that He became man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:204
verses.text: Thus then, too, though demonstrated as God, He does not refuse the conditions proper to Him as man, since He hungers and toils and thirsts in weariness, and flees in fear, and prays in trouble.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:205
verses.text: And He who as God has a sleepless nature, slumbers on a pillow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:206
verses.text: And He who for this end came into the world, begs off from the cup of suffering.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:207
verses.text: And in an agony He sweats blood, and is strengthened by an angel, who Himself strengthens those who believe on Him, and taught men to despise death by His work.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:208
verses.text: And He who knew what manner of man Judas was, is betrayed by Judas.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:209
verses.text: And He, who formerly was honoured by him as God, is contemned by Caiaphas.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:210
verses.text: And He is set at nought by Herod, who is Himself to judge the whole earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:211
verses.text: And He is scourged by Pilate, who took upon Himself our infirmities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:212
verses.text: And by the soldiers He is mocked, at whose behest stand thousands of thousands and myriads of myriads of angels and archangels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:213
verses.text: And He who fixed the heavens like a vault is fastened to the cross by the Jews.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:214
verses.text: And He who is inseparable from the Father cries to the Father, and commends to Him His spirit; and bowing His head, He gives up the ghost, who said, "I have power to lay down my life, and I have power to take it again;" and because He was not overmastered by death, as being Himself Life, He said this:  "I lay it down of myself".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:215
verses.text: And He who gives life bountifully to all, has His side pierced with a spear.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:216
verses.text: And He who raises the dead is wrapped in linen and laid in a sepulchre, and on the third day He is raised again by the Father, though Himself the Resurrection and the Life.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:217
verses.text: For all these things has He finished for us, who for our sakes was made as we are.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:218
verses.text: For "Himself hath borne our infirmities, and carried our diseases; and for our sakes He was afflicted," as Isaiah the prophet has said.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:219
verses.text: This is He who was hymned by the angels, and seen by the shepherds, and waited for by Simeon, and witnessed to by Anna.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:220
verses.text: This is He who was inquired after by the wise men, and indicated by the star; He who was engaged in His Father's house, and pointed to by John, and witnessed to by the Father from above in the voice, "This is my beloved Son; hear ye Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:221
verses.text: He is crowned victor against the devil.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:222
verses.text: This is Jesus of Nazareth, who was invited to the marriage-feast in Cana, and turned the water into wine, and rebuked the sea when agitated by the violence of the winds, and walked on the deep as on dry land, and caused the blind man from birth to see, and raised Lazarus to life after he had been dead four days, and did many mighty works, and forgave sins, and conferred power on the disciples, and had blood and water flowing from His sacred side when pierced with the spear.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:223
verses.text: For His sake the sun is darkened, the day has no light, the rocks are shattered, the veil is rent, the foundations of the earth are shaken, the graves are opened, and the dead are raised, and the rulers are ashamed when they see the Director of the universe upon the cross closing His eye and giving up the ghost.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:224
verses.text: Creation saw, and was troubled; and, unable to bear the sight of His exceeding glory, shrouded itself in darkness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:225
verses.text: This (is He who) breathes upon the disciples, and gives them the Spirit, and comes in among them when the doors are shut, and is taken up by a cloud into the heavens while the disciples gaze at Him, and is set down on the right hand of the Father, and comes again as the Judge of the living and the dead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:226
verses.text: This is the God who for our sakes became man, to whom also the Father hath put all things in subjection.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:227
verses.text: To Him be the glory and the power, with the Father and the Holy Spirit, in the holy Church both now and ever, and even for evermore.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 4:228
verses.text: Amen.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:1
verses.text: Against Beron and Helix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:2
verses.text: Fragments of a discourse, alphabetically divided, on the Divine Nature and the Incarnation, against the heretics Beron and Helix, the beginning of which was in these words, "Holy, holy, holy, Lord God of Sabaoth, with voice never silent the seraphim exclaim and glorify God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:3
verses.text: Fragment I.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:4
verses.text: By the omnipotent will of God all things are made, and the things that are made are also preserved, being maintained according to their several principles in perfect harmony by Him who is in His nature the omnipotent God and maker of all things, His divine will remaining unalterable by which He has made and moves all things, sustained as they severally are by their own natural laws.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:5
verses.text: For the infinite cannot in any manner or by any account be susceptible of movement, inasmuch as it has nothing towards which and nothing around which it shall be moved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:6
verses.text: For in the case of that which is in its nature infinite, and so incapable of being moved, movement would be conversion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:7
verses.text: Wherefore also the Word of God being made truly man in our manner, yet without sin, and acting and enduring in man's way such sinless things as are proper to our nature, and assuming the circumscription of the flesh of our nature on our behalf, sustained no conversion in that aspect in which He is one with the Father, being made in no respect one with the flesh through the exinanition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:8
verses.text: But as He was without flesh, He remained without any circumscription.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:9
verses.text: And through the flesh He wrought divinely those things which are proper to divinity, showing Himself to have both those natures in both of which He wrought, I mean the divine and the human, according to that veritable and real and natural subsistence, (showing Himself thus) as both being in reality and as being understood to be at one and the same time infinite God and finite man, having the nature of each in perfection, with the same activity, that is to say, the same natural properties; whence we know that their distinction abides always according to the nature of each, and without conversion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:10
verses.text: But it is not (i-e:, the distinction between deity and humanity), as some say, a merely comparative (or relative) matter, that we may not speak in an unwarrantable manner of a greater and a less in one who is ever the same in Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:11
verses.text: For comparisons can be instituted only between objects of like nature, and not between objects of unlike nature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:12
verses.text: But between God the Maker of all things and that which is made, between the infinite and the finite, between infinitude and finitude, there can be no kind of comparison, since these differ from each other not in mere comparison (or relatively), but absolutely in essence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:13
verses.text: And yet at the same time there has been effected a certain inexpressible and irrefragable union of the two into one substance, which entirely passes the understanding of anything that is made.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 5:14
verses.text: For the divine is just the same after the incarnation that it was before the incarnation; in its essence infinite, illimitable, impassible, incomparable, unchangeable, inconvertable, self-potent, and, in short, subsisting in essence alone the infinitely worthy good.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:1
verses.text: Fragment II.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:2
verses.text: The God of all things therefore became truly, according to the Scriptures, without conversion, sinless man, and that in a manner known to Himself alone, as He is the natural Artificer of things which are above our comprehension.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:3
verses.text: And by that same saving act of the incarnation He introduced into the flesh the activity of His proper divinity, yet without having it (that activity) either circumscribed by the flesh through the exinanition, or growing naturally out of the flesh as it grew out of His divinity, but manifested through it in the things which He wrought in a divine manner in His incarnate state.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:4
verses.text: For the flesh did not become divinity in nature by a transmutation of nature, as though it became essentially flesh of divinity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:5
verses.text: But what it was before, that also it continued to be in nature and activity when united with divinity, even as the Saviour said, "The spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:6
verses.text: And working and enduring in the flesh things which were proper to sinless flesh, He proved the evacuation of divinity (to be) for our sakes, confirmed as it was by wonders and by sufferings of the flesh naturally.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:7
verses.text: For with this purpose did the God of all things become man, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:8
verses.text: , in order that by suffering in the flesh, which is susceptible of suffering, He might redeem our whole race, which was sold to death; and that by working wondrous things by His divinity, which is unsusceptible of suffering, through the medium of the flesh He might restore it to that incorruptible and blessed life from which it fell away by yielding to the devil; and that He might establish the holy orders of intelligent existences in the heavens in immutability by the mystery of His incarnation, the doing of which is the recapitulation of all things in himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 6:9
verses.text: He remained therefore, also, after His incarnation, according to nature, God infinite, and more, having the activity proper and suitable to Himself,—an activity growing out of His divinity essentially, and manifested through His perfectly holy flesh by wondrous acts economically, to the intent that He might be believed in as God, while working out of Himself by the flesh, which by nature is weak, the salvation of the universe.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7:1
verses.text: Fragment III.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7:2
verses.text: Now, with the view of explaining, by means of an illustration, what has been said concerning the Saviour, (I may say that) the power of thought which I have by nature is proper and suitable to me, as being possessed of a rational and intelligent soul; and to this soul there pertains, according to nature, a self-moved energy and first power, ever-moving, to wit, the thought that streams from it naturally.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7:3
verses.text: This thought I utter, when there is occasion, by fitting it to words, and expressing it rightly in signs, using the tongue as an organ, or artificial characters, showing that it is heard, though it comes into actuality by means of objects foreign to itself, and yet is not changed itself by those foreign objects.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7:4
verses.text: For my natural thought does not belong to the tongue or the letters, although I effect its utterance by means of these; but it belongs to me, who speak according to my nature, and by means of both these express it as my own, streaming as it does always from my intelligent soul according to its nature, and uttered by means of my bodily tongue organically, as I have said, when there is occasion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7:5
verses.text: Now, to institute a comparison with that which is utterly beyond comparison, just as in us the power of thought that belongs by nature to the soul is brought to utterance by means of our bodily tongue without any change in itself, so, too, in the wondrous incarnation of God is the omnipotent and all-creating energy of the entire deity manifested without mutation in itself, by means of His perfectly holy flesh, and in the works which He wrought after a divine manner, (that energy of the deity) remaining in its essence free from all circumscription, although it shone through the flesh, which is itself essentially limited.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7:6
verses.text: For that which is in its nature unoriginated cannot be circumscribed by an originated nature, although this latter may have grown into one with it by a conception which circumscribes all understanding: nor can this be ever brought into the same nature and natural activity with that, so long as they remain each within its own proper and inconvertible nature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 7:7
verses.text: For it is only in objects of the same nature that there is the motion that works the same works, showing that the being whose power is natural is incapable in any manner of being or becoming the possession of a being of a different nature without mutation.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 8

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 8:1
verses.text: Fragment IV.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 8:2
verses.text: For, in the view of apostles and prophets and teachers, the mystery of the divine incarnation has been distinguished as having two points of contemplation natural to it, distinct in all things, inasmuch as on the one hand it is the subsistence of perfect deity, and on the other is demonstrative of full humanity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 8:3
verses.text: As long, therefore, as the Word is acknowledged to be in substance one, of one energy, there shall never in any way be known a movement in the two.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 8:4
verses.text: For while God, who is essentially ever-existent, became by His infinite power, according to His will, sinless man, He is what He was, in all wherein God is known; and what He became, He is in all wherein man is known and can be recognised.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 8:5
verses.text: In both aspects of Himself He never falls out of Himself, in His divine activities and in His human alike, preserving in both relations His own essentially unchangeable perfection.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9:1
verses.text: Fragment V.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9:2
verses.text: For lately a certain person, Beron, along with some others, forsook the delusion of Valentinus, only to involve themselves in deeper error, affirming that the flesh assumed to Himself by the Word became capable of working like works with the deity by virtue of its assumption, and that the deity became susceptible of suffering in the same way with the flesh by virtue of the exinanition; and thus they assert the doctrine that there was at the same time a conversion and a mixing and a fusing of the two aspects one with the other.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9:3
verses.text: For if the flesh that was assumed became capable of working like works with the deity, it is evident that it also became God in essence in all wherein God is essentially known.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9:4
verses.text: And if the deity by the exinanition became susceptible of the same sufferings with the flesh, it is evident that it also became in essence flesh in all wherein flesh essentially can be known.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9:5
verses.text: For objects that act in like manner, and work like works, and are altogether of like kind, and are susceptible of like suffering with each other, admit of no difference of nature; and if the natures are fused together, Christ will be a duality; and if the persons are separated, there will be a quaternity,—a thing which is altogether to be avoided.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9:6
verses.text: And how will they conceive of the one and the same Christ, who is at once God and man by nature? And what manner of existence will He have according to them, if He has become man by a conversion of the deity, and if he has become God by a change of the flesh? For the mutation of these, the one into the other, is a complete subversion of both.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 9:7
verses.text: Let the discussion, then, be considered by us again in a different way.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 10

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 10:1
verses.text: Fragment VI.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 10:2
verses.text: Among Christians it is settled as the doctrine of piety, that, according to nature itself, and to the activity and to whatever else pertains thereunto, God is equal and the same with Himself, having nothing that is His unequal to Himself at all and heterogeneous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 10:3
verses.text: If, then, according to Beron, the flesh that He assumed to Himself became possessed of the like natural energy with them, it is evident that it also became possessed of the like nature with Him in all wherein that nature consists,—to wit, non-origination, non-generation, infinitude, eternity, incomprehensibility, and whatever else in the way of the transcendent the theological mind discerns in deity; and thus they both underwent conversion, neither the one nor the other preserving any more the substantial relation of its own proper nature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 10:4
verses.text: For he who recognises an identical operation in things of unlike nature, introduces at the same time a fusion of natures and a separation of persons, their natural existence being made entirely undistinguishable by the transference of properties.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 11

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 11:1
verses.text: Fragment VII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 11:2
verses.text: But if it (the flesh) did not become of like nature with that (the deity), neither shall it ever become of like natural energy with that; that He may not be shown to have His energy unequal with His nature, and heterogeneous, and, through all that pertains to Himself, to have entered on an existence outside of His natural equality and identity, which is an impious supposition.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:1
verses.text: Fragment VIII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:2
verses.text: Into this error, then, have they been carried, by believing, unhappily, that that divine energy was made the property of the flesh which was only manifested through the flesh in His miraculous actions; by which energy Christ, in so far as He is apprehended as God, gave existence to the universe, and now maintains and governs it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:3
verses.text: For they did not perceive that it is impossible for the energy of the divine nature to become the property of a being of a different nature apart from conversion; nor did they understand that that is not by any means the property of the flesh which is only manifested through it, and does not spring out of it according to nature; and yet the proof thereof was clear and evident to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:4
verses.text: For I, by speaking with the tongue and writing with the hand, reveal through both these one and the same thought of my intelligent soul, its energy (or operation) being natural; in no way showing it as springing naturally out of tongue or hand; nor yet (showing) even the spoken thought as made to belong to them in virtue of its revelation by their means.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:5
verses.text: For no intelligent person ever recognised tongue or hand as capable of thought, just as also no one ever recognised the perfectly holy flesh of God, in virtue of its assumption, and in virtue of the revelation of the divine energy through its medium, as becoming in nature creative.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:6
verses.text: But the pious confession of the believer is that, with a view to our salvation, and in order to connect the universe with unchangeableness, the Creator of all things incorporated with Himself a rational soul and a sensible body from the all-holy Mary, ever-virgin, by an undefiled conception, without conversion, and was made man in nature, but separate from wickedness: the same was perfect God, and the same was perfect man; the same was in nature at once perfect God and man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:7
verses.text: In His deity He wrought divine things through His all-holy flesh,—such things, namely, as did not pertain to the flesh by nature; and in His humanity He suffered human things,—such things, namely, as did not pertain to deity by nature, by the upbearing of the deity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:8
verses.text: He wrought nothing divine without the body; nor did the same do anything human without the participation of deity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:9
verses.text: Thus He preserved for Himself a new and fitting method by which He wrought (according to the manner of) both, while that which was natural to both remained unchanged; to the accrediting of His perfect incarnation, which is really genuine, and has nothing lacking in it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 12:10
verses.text: Beron, therefore, since the case stands with him as I have already stated, confounding together in nature the deity and the humanity of Christ in a single energy, and again separating them in person, subverts the life, not knowing that identical operation is indicative of the connatural identity only of connatural persons.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:1
verses.text: The Discourse on the Holy Theophany.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:2
verses.text: Good, yea, very good, are all the works of our God and Saviour—all of them that eye seeth and mind perceiveth, all that reason interprets and hand handles, all that intellect comprehends and human nature understands.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:3
verses.text: For what richer beauty can there be than that of the circle of heaven? And what form of more blooming fairness than that of earth's surface? And what is there swifter in the course than the chariot of the sun? And what more graceful car than the lunar orb? And what work more wonderful than the compact mosaic of the stars? And what more productive of supplies than the seasonable winds? And what more spotless mirror than the light of day? And what creature more excellent than man? Very good, then, are all the works of our God and Saviour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:4
verses.text: And what more requisite gift, again, is there than the element of water? For with water all things are washed and nourished, and cleansed and bedewed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:5
verses.text: Water bears the earth, water produces the dew, water exhilarates the vine; water matures the corn in the ear, water ripens the grapecluster, water softens the olive, water sweetens the palm-date, water reddens the rose and decks the violet, water makes the lily bloom with its brilliant cups.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:6
verses.text: And why should I speak at length? Without the element of water, none of the present order of things can subsist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:7
verses.text: So necessary is the element of water; for the other elements took their places beneath the highest vault of the heavens, but the nature of water obtained a seat also above the heavens.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:8
verses.text: And to this the prophet himself is a witness, when he exclaims, "Praise the Lord, ye heavens of heavens, and the water that is above the heavens".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:9
verses.text: Nor is this the only thing that proves the dignity of the water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:10
verses.text: But there is also that which is more honourable than all—the fact that Christ, the Maker of all, came down as the rain, and was known as a spring, and diffused Himself as a river, and was baptized in the Jordan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:11
verses.text: For you have just heard how Jesus came to John, and was baptized by him in the Jordan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:12
verses.text: Oh things strange beyond compare! How should the boundless River that makes glad the city of God have been dipped in a little water! The illimitable Spring that bears life to all men, and has no end, was covered by poor and temporary waters! He who is present everywhere, and absent nowhere—who is incomprehensible to angels and invisible to men—comes to the baptism according to His own good pleasure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:13
verses.text: When you hear these things, beloved, take them not as if spoken literally, but accept them as presented in a figure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:14
verses.text: Whence also the Lord was not unnoticed by the watery element in what He did in secret, in the kindness of His condescension to man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:15
verses.text: "For the waters saw Him, and were afraid".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:16
verses.text: They well-nigh broke from their place, and burst away from their boundary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:17
verses.text: Hence the prophet, having this in his view many generations ago, puts the question, "What aileth thee, O sea, that thou fleddest; and thou, Jordan, that thou wast driven back?" And they in reply said, We have seen the Creator of all things in the "form of a servant," and being ignorant of the mystery of the economy, we were lashed with fear.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:18
verses.text: But we, who know the economy, adore His mercy, because He hath come to save and not to judge the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:19
verses.text: Wherefore John, the forerunner of the Lord, who before knew not this mystery, on learning that He is Lord in truth, cried out, and spake to those who came to be baptized of him, "O generation of vipers," why look ye so earnestly at me? "I am not the Christ;" I am the servant, and not the lord; I am the subject, and not the king; I am the sheep, and not the shepherd; I am a man, and not God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:20
verses.text: By my birth I loosed the barrenness of my mother; I did not make virginity barren.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:21
verses.text: I was brought up from beneath; I did not come down from above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:22
verses.text: I bound the tongue of my father; I did not unfold divine grace.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:23
verses.text: I was known by my mother, and I was not announced by a star.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:24
verses.text: I am worthless, and the least; but "after me there comes One who is before me"—after me, indeed, in time, but before me by reason of the inaccessible and unutterable light of divinity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:25
verses.text: "There comes One mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to bear: He shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost, and with fire".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:26
verses.text: I am subject to authority, but He has authority in Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:27
verses.text: I am bound by sins, but He is the Remover of sins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:28
verses.text: I apply the law, but He bringeth grace to light.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:29
verses.text: I teach as a slave, but He judgeth as the Master.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:30
verses.text: I have the earth as my couch, but He possesses heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:31
verses.text: I baptize with the baptism of repentance, but He confers the gift of adoption: "He shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost, and with fire".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:32
verses.text: Why give ye attention to me? I am not the Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:33
verses.text: As John says these things to the multitude, and as the people watch in eager expectation of seeing some strange spectacle with their bodily eyes, and the devil is struck with amazement at such a testimony from John, lo, the Lord appears, plain, solitary, uncovered, without escort, having on Him the body of man like a garment, and hiding the dignity of the Divinity, that He may elude the snares of the dragon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:34
verses.text: And not only did He approach John as Lord without royal retinue; but even like a mere man, and one involved in sin, He bent His head to be baptized by John.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:35
verses.text: Wherefore John, on seeing so great a humbling of Himself, was struck with astonishment at the affair, and began to prevent Him, saying, as ye have just heard, "I have need to be baptized of Thee, and comest Thou to me?" What doest Thou, O Lord? Thou teachest things not according to rule.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:36
verses.text: I have preached one thing (regarding Thee), and Thou performest another; the devil has heard one thing, and perceives another.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:37
verses.text: Baptize me with the fire of Divinity; why waitest Thou for water? Enlighten me with the Spirit; why dost Thou attend upon a creature? Baptize me, the Baptist, that Thy pre-eminence may be known.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:38
verses.text: I, O Lord, baptize with the baptism of repentance, and I cannot baptize those who come to me unless they first confess fully their sins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:39
verses.text: Be it so then that I baptize Thee, what hast Thou to confess? Thou art the Remover of sins, and wilt Thou be baptized with the baptism of repentance? Though I should venture to baptize Thee, the Jordan dares not to come near Thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:40
verses.text: "I have need to be baptized of Thee, and comest Thou to me?".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:41
verses.text: And what saith the Lord to him?  "Suffer it to be so now, for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:42
verses.text: "Suffer it to be so now," John; thou art not wiser than I.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:43
verses.text: Thou seest as man; I foreknow as God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:44
verses.text: It becomes me to do this first, and thus to teach.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:45
verses.text: I engage in nothing unbecoming, for I am invested with honour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:46
verses.text: Dost thou marvel, O John, that I am not come in my dignity? The purple robe of kings suits not one in private station, but military splendour suits a king: am I come to a prince, and not to a friend? "Suffer it to be so now for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness:" I am the Fulfiller of the law; I seek to leave nothing wanting to its whole fulfilment, that so after me Paul may exclaim, "Christ is the fulfilling of the law for righteousness to every one that believeth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:47
verses.text: "Suffer it to be so now, for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:48
verses.text: Baptize me, John, in order that no one may despise baptism.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:49
verses.text: I am baptized by thee, the servant, that no one among kings or dignitaries may scorn to be baptized by the hand of a poor priest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:50
verses.text: Suffer me to go down into the Jordan, in order that they may hear my Father's testimony, and recognise the power of the Son.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:51
verses.text: "Suffer it to be so now, for thus it becometh us to fulfil all righteousness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:52
verses.text: Then at length John suffers Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:53
verses.text: "And Jesus, when He was baptized, went up straightway out of the water: and the heavens were opened unto Him; and, lo, the Spirit of God descended like a dove, and rested upon Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:54
verses.text: And a voice (came) from heaven, saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:55
verses.text: Do you see, beloved, how many and how great blessings we would have lost, if the Lord had yielded to the exhortation of John, and declined baptism? For the heavens were shut before this; the region above was inaccessible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:56
verses.text: We would in that case descend to the lower parts, but we would not ascend to the upper.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:57
verses.text: But was it only that the Lord was baptized? He also renewed the old man, and committed to him again the sceptre of adoption.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:58
verses.text: For straightway "the heavens were opened to Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:59
verses.text: A reconciliation took place of the visible with the invisible; the celestial orders were filled with joy; the diseases of earth were healed; secret things were made known; those at enmity were restored to amity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:60
verses.text: For you have heard the word of the evangelist, saying, "The heavens were opened to Him," on account of three wonders.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:61
verses.text: For when Christ the Bridegroom was baptized, it was meet that the bridal-chamber of heaven should open its brilliant gates.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:62
verses.text: And in like manner also, when the Holy Spirit descended in the form of a dove, and the Father's voice spread everywhere, it was meet that "the gates of heaven should be lifted up".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:63
verses.text: "And, lo, the heavens were opened to Him; and a voice was heard, saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:64
verses.text: The beloved generates love, and the light immaterial the light inaccessible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:65
verses.text: "This is my beloved Son," He who, being manifested on earth and yet unseparated from the Father's bosom, was manifested, and yet did not appear.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:66
verses.text: For the appearing is a different thing, since in appearance the baptizer here is superior to the baptized.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:67
verses.text: For this reason did the Father send down the Holy Spirit from heaven upon Him who was baptized.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:68
verses.text: For as in the ark of Noah the love of God toward man is signified by the dove, so also now the Spirit, descending in the form of a dove, bearing as it were the fruit of the olive, rested on Him to whom the witness was borne.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:69
verses.text: For what reason? That the faithfulness of the Father's voice might be made known, and that the prophetic utterance of a long time past might be ratified.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:70
verses.text: And what utterance is this? "The voice of the Lord (is) on the waters, the God of glory thundered; the Lord (is) upon many waters".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:71
verses.text: And what voice? "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:72
verses.text: This is He who is named the son of Joseph, and (who is) according to the divine essence my Only-begotten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:73
verses.text: "This is my beloved Son"—He who is hungry, and yet maintains myriads; who is weary, and yet gives rest to the weary; who has not where to lay His head, and yet bears up all things in His hand; who suffers, and yet heals sufferings; who is smitten, and yet confers liberty on the world; who is pierced in the side, and yet repairs the side of Adam.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:74
verses.text: But give me now your best attention, I pray you, for I wish to go back to the fountain of life, and to view the fountain that gushes with healing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:75
verses.text: The Father of immortality sent the immortal Son and Word into the world, who came to man in order to wash him with water and the Spirit; and He, begetting us again to incorruption of soul and body, breathed into us the breath (spirit) of life, and endued us with an incorruptible panoply.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:76
verses.text: If, therefore, man has become immortal, he will also be God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:77
verses.text: And if he is made God by water and the Holy Spirit after the regeneration of the laver he is found to be also joint-heir with Christ after the resurrection from the dead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:78
verses.text: Wherefore I preach to this effect: Come, all ye kindreds of the nations, to the immortality of the baptism.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:79
verses.text: I bring good tidings of life to you who tarry in the darkness of ignorance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:80
verses.text: Come into liberty from slavery, into a kingdom from tyranny, into incorruption from corruption.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:81
verses.text: And how, saith one, shall we come? How? By water and the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:82
verses.text: This is the water in conjunction with the Spirit, by which paradise is watered, by which the earth is enriched, by which plants grow, by which animals multiply, and (to sum up the whole in a single word) by which man is begotten again and endued with life, in which also Christ was baptized, and in which the Spirit descended in the form of a dove.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:83
verses.text: This is the Spirit that at the beginning "moved upon the face of the waters;" by whom the world moves; by whom creation consists, and all things have life; who also wrought mightily in the prophets, and descended in flight upon Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:84
verses.text: This is the Spirit that was given to the apostles in the form of fiery tongues.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:85
verses.text: This is the Spirit that David sought when he said, "Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:86
verses.text: Of this Spirit Gabriel also spoke to the Virgin, "The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:87
verses.text: By this Spirit Peter spake that blessed word, "Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:88
verses.text: By this Spirit the rock of the Church was stablished.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Dogmatic and Historical 13:89
